movie_review_blurb: Bata-ville is a strange homage to a mystified, iconic Bata, but offers little insight into the empire's true story other than the overused, overdramatized slogan We are not afraid of the future.
movie_title: Bata-ville: We Are Not Afraid of the Future (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The documentary is only beautiful on the surface.
movie_title: Manolo, The Boy Who Made Shoes For Lizards (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As usual, this latest Perry Madea flick is all about laughs - nothing less and nothing more. With Boo!, you'll laugh hard, even when the jokes feel too slapsticky, too vulgar, too over-the-top.
movie_title: Tyler Perry's Boo! A Madea Halloween (2016)

Sadly, the film simply isn't hugely funny.
Not only does this film not manage to stick the landing, but it doesn't even try to land in the first place.

movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Fake WMD and super-shaky cam: It's The Paul Greengrass Experience.

movie_review_blurb: Summit Entertainment has tried just a little too hard to broaden the appeal of its new computer-animated feature Astro Boy.
This is a movie that does little more than preach to the converted. It's mildly amusing at times, but ultimately pointless.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Not quite a coming-of-age movie and not quite an examination of the early work of Orson Welles, it's an odd melange of the two that never quite comes together in a satisfying way.
Robert Zemeckis seeks to answer the one question still remaining about the Dickens classic: What would the story look like if it were cast with figures from Madame Tussauds?

movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: 160 minutes of this nonsense is at least 90 minutes of back story too many.

Harrowing and sometimes hard to watch, Precious is a tale of unrelenting misery that suggests just enough of a silver lining to keep audiences from spiraling into total depression.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A feel-good sports drama about the intersection of race and athletics, with solid if unremarkable performances that strains just a little too hard for social relevance

Incredibly dull and generic.

movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Hurt Locker is an action-packed thriller of the first order, the most entertaining movie to be made to date about the Iraq war.

movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: $9.99 is consistently amusing but rarely laugh-out-loud funny.

A sloppy, second-rate entry in the catalog of standalone X-Files adventures.

movie_review_blurb: The Dark Knight is a masterpiece of the first order, and the first great post-Sept. 11 film.
Few films have accepted the role of Matrix knockoff with such gusto as Wanted; indeed, at times it's almost impossible to distinguish the two.

Though not quite as funny as Office Space and almost certainly less quotable, Extract skillfully mines both the workplace and personal space for moments of hilarity.
The look of the characters ... is incredibly intriguing, and the universe that Messrs. Acker, Burton and Bekmambetov have created is a treat for the eyes.
The Baader Meinhof Complex is a taut and involving thriller that is at its strongest when it focuses on the ideological evolution of Ulrike Meinhof (Martina Gedeck).
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Though there are moments of comedy, Paul's abrasiveness makes it too hard to give oneself over to the humor and accept it on its own terms.
Unfortunately, Jennifer's Body is neither laugh-out-loud funny nor cringe-inducingly frightening.
There are some humorous and touching moments in Baghead, but the actors lack the finesse needed to make us really feel for their characters.
Pride and Glory doesn't add anything to the generic crooked-cop procedural that we haven't seen with more verve in better movies.
There's a slightly darker edge to The Grand Budapest Hotel than Anderson's previous efforts.
There are a number of gut-bustingly funny individual scenes, but the narrative as a whole lacks thematic cohesion.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: With Coraline, Henry Selick and his team of stop-motion animators have created a real wonder, one that will entertain children for years to come.
It's unlikely that anyone over 10 will find much to cheer in this film, and adults will just be depressed by seeing a once-cutting-edge wit like Mr. Martin debasing himself.
Taken is a fast-paced, high-octane action movie that ... doesn't take very many detours into soul-searching melancholy.
Kelly Reichardt spends the 75 minutes of Wendy and Lucy weaving an intimate, narrowly focused story of unanchored life on the road and just how tenuous such an existence is.
Waltz is a challenging film in the best sense of the word. It asks questions about the nature of memory and life during a time of war without providing any pat answers.
Defiance is overly long and somewhat disjointed, dragging through an interminable second act that seriously impedes the film's flow and hurts the inspired performances.
Though it never quite devolves into pure hagiography, the film's central tale of crack dealer made good is sometimes a little too hokey for its own good.
Revolutionary Road is content to stick with hoary cliches about the emptiness of middle-class bourgeois life.
It's a testament to Mr. Rourke's talent that Randy's life and attempted redemption never devolve into maudlin, unearned sentimentality.
Maintaining tension in the face of a foregone conclusion is no mean trick, but Mr. Singer and company do as well as anyone could hope.
If this is the end of the road for the Man With No Name, it's a memorable, winning way for him to go out.
Mr. Carrey's performance is a return to the rubber-faced roles that dominated multiplexes in the mid- to late '90s, and that's not necessarily a good thing.
The ending will divide viewers. Some will shed tears, others will be outraged. It's a bold artistic choice, but one of questionable morality.
An entirely unnecessary and unremarkable remake.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A more linear, shorter narrative that featured a few less musical interludes by Mr. Jal would have improved this documentary considerably.
One can assume another reboot will be in the offing after this monstrosity tanks at the box office.

It's hard not to get sucked in--if one can get past the sometimes hokey, melodramatic teenage dialogue.
Quantum of Solace feels more like a competent second act than a stand-alone film.

this is a moody, original take on the vampire film. ... Anyone interested in vampire films or relationship films will enjoy this fantastic picture

I laughed out loud a couple of times. It's not as funny as it needs to be to make it a must-watch in theaters, but it's not so terrible that you should avoid it at all costs.
Among the most engrossing 80-or-so minutes you'll see all year.
Much to my surprise, I quite enjoyed La La Land. And I imagine most moviegoers will too.
The first 'Star Wars Story' is a success.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Pretty much perfect.
I can't remember the last time I saw a film about faith that treated the subject with such seriousness and reflection and artistry.
At its best, Patriots Day is extremely effective filmmaking. ... It is too bad ... that the rest of the film is less taut.
You have to see Split on its opening weekend.
Arrival is a magnificently made movie and likely the best I've seen so far this year. See it as soon as possible and on as big a screen as you can. You don't want to miss out.

A worthy sequel to the best American action film of the 2010s.
Grotesque, but not in the good way, like you want.
A fitting finale for Jackman that sometimes falters in its urge to please.

Completely unnecessary live-action retread of a beloved Disney classic.

Throwback war film among best, bloodiest of the year.
I'm not saying Irrfan Khan should definitely win best supporting actor at the Oscars, but he should be on the shortlist for kinda-sorta saving this easily skipped picture.
Nothing about this film makes sense.

The film as a whole is a real mess. Not that it matters. The Chinese market is going to ensure that we are treated to Warcraft stories for years to come.

[Kirsten Stewart's] one of the most interesting actresses working today, and is worth seeking out, even on VOD.

movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The best joke in the movie is one that comes at the expense of fans.
The most fun I've had at the theater so far this year.

You should skip it because it's worse than incompetent: It's soulless.

movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Luc Besson shows and then tells - and tells, and tells, and tells.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

A rather perfect mlange of casual wealth porn, a glimpse into competitive friendships, and the clash between masculine imperatives.
Stephen King's scariest book earns a solid, if minor, adaptation

A shockingly bad piece of work.

A surprisingly funny film that lands just enough jokes not to desecrate its predecessor. Sometimes the soft bigotry of low expectations is a blessing, not a curse.

movie_review_blurb: This is a tale of hubris and tragedy, a reminder that pushing oneself solely for the point of pushing oneself is not a particularly good use of one's time on this planet.

If you are a fan of Carrey's comedic talents, and if you just want a few laughs, Bruce Almighty is all-righty, then.
Out of all the movies I've seen this year so far, The Italian Job was definitely the most fun and entertaining.
2 Fast 2 Furious... 2 flawed

The special effects and CGI, uneven in Sorcerer's Stone, are all spit-shine and shoe-polish in Chamber of Secrets. There isn't one hair out of place.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Whether our action-and-popcorn obsessed culture will embrace this engaging and literate psychodrama isn't much of a mystery, unfortunately.
The dialogue sizzles with scalding wit, and you will have to look far and wide for a more morbidly fascinating opening sequence. It really hooks you.

You get a lot of 'Bang' for your buck!

The plot is pretty threadbare, but Chan's inventive fight choreography leaves you hanging by a thread.

I must say it's one of the most insidious, thought-provoking films to come out this year. Still, I can't quite recommend it.

Below is well below expectations.
...they missed the boat.
...Dare I say it? The Hulk is incredible!

Romance with a capital R ensues, love conquers all and so on and so forth. It's clichd (yet makes fun of itself in the process) but cute.
[One among many] the moment of suspense as shiny Red Delicious meets sweet lips is truly chilling.
Hokey CGI; if the budget wasn't enough to make the effects good enough, they should have been left out entirely.
The Wall is certainly [an] absorbing and intensely thought-provoking film.
Excellently-acted, beautifully shot and deliberately-paced to nail-biting perfection, Blue Ruin takes a deserved place in the pantheon of no-holds-barred revenge thrillers.
The locations, costumes, and fantastic cinematography and editing present a time-capsule of pure wow.
While the sociopolitical aspects of the film are undeniably interesting, it's an entertaining but ultimately uneven and unfulfilling experience at best.
Not a lot happens in the film; it's mostly musings and the cacophony of monotony of day-to-day life, yet there is a spiritedness in the work that's quite unique to its director, Agns Varda.
While there's a lot to draw from here, there was perhaps too much Lelio found precious; a sagging center [does the film no favors].
Although a lot of it is talking heads, I was never once bored: the editing and presentation are every bit as dynamic as the anecdotes.
A must-see for filmmakers, aficionados, dreamers, doers and 'warriors' of all ilk.

Lacking the suspense and grip of flicks like The Thing or even minimalist stranded-in-space cinema like Moon, Last Days is saved from total tedium only by competent first-time director Ruairi Robinson and its stellar cast.
Enjoyable enough for both the completest and the casual costume drama fan.
Style rules over substance here, and what style it is!
movie_title: The Strange Color of Your Body's Tears (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Peerless performances stayed with solid cinematography, a stirring score, and especially dishy dialogue, make Saving Mr. Banks is a solid biopic.
As straight-laced as its Victorian-era setting, the film lacks gusto.
Homefront reminded me a lot of an old fashioned, really rated R, 1970s Jan Michael Vincent or Charles Bronson vehicle.
Contracted goes all-out on the gross-out.
It's sure to please inquiring minds of both left- and right-brained nature.
Like a combination of the Penn & Teller: Bulls***! TV series and an extended episode of MythBusters as presented by an alternate History Channel comes Tim's Vermeer - a truly fascinating documentary.
Deftly directed, Barnard's film gives just as much credence to quiet dialogue scenes as it does to a danger-fraught harness pace-race that's reminiscent of Ben Hur on a budget.
Maniac is an elegant and carefully crafted film, from start to finish.
People who haven't seen the original will love it, and people who have seen the original should at least like it.
Deft direction, strong performances, and an absorbing story elevate Haunter to the status of one of the better 'family' horror films of recent years.
As a science fiction action extravaganza, I can't fault the latest from director Zack Snyder. But as a fun Superman comic book popcorn flick, I certainly can.
London: The Modern Babylon is, as a whole, a highly educational and extremely entertaining overview of 'The Smoke'.
...a big, dumb home invasion horror movie.
World War Z is not a horror film, nor is it a deeply thought-provoking political thriller. But it is a fine action picture, and a good Brad Pitt movie.
It's great.

Clad throughout most of the film donning nothing but his retractable knuckle-claws, muttonchops, and a body cut enough to put Ginsu out of business, Jackman actually does a great job of portraying the human, emotional side of the eponymous mutant.
In spite of the uneasy straddle between crime-thriller and true-story, the movie's got its moments.
Writer/director Renaud Gauthier shows he's got lots of potential. I look forward to seeing what he does next.
Add the swinging '70s vibe to some cool costuming and an even groovier soundtrack, and you've got an entertaining (if sobering) night at the movies.
Curse of Chucky is nicely restrained, eking out suspense and building characters before all voodoo hell breaks loose.
A head-shaker of a twist undoes all the good built up in the beginning.
movie_title: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The film looks picturesque as can be, is well-acted, and very smartly plotted.
Yes, it's formulaic; but thrillingly so. Yes, it's more accessible than arty; but it's still a handcrafted film.
Highly entertaining.
One of the best of the year.
Don't let the generic title, or the lack of household names, deter you. Horror Stories lives up to its name and then some.
There's enough gleeful use of T-N-T in this fun-fare flick to make Wile E. Coyote look like Mahatma Gandhi.
Sexual harassment all dressed up and nowhere to go.
The story is standard issue: good vs. evil. But the presentation is quite magical, and briskly-paced.
More than anything, Skyfall is about the Bond girls. They've come a long way, baby. Fully-formed, strong-thinking, and smart, pivotal characters, Skyfall focuses firmly on M, and rookie Eve.
Unless you are a diehard, and preferably desperate, fan of Asian monster movies it's probably best you sidestep Sector 7.
Tennessee Williams meets Nabokov meets The Coen Brothers in this dark, cruel, funny and weirdly amiable hicksploitation chamber-piece.
[Mostly slow, this film at least] has some absorbing moments of strange sexuality, haunt and mystery.
How much you like Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter will be predicated quite a bit on how much you like Timur Bekmambetov's movies.

SGWKP is a slow but absorbing character study reminiscent of genre mash-ups like Baghead, Lars & The Real Girl, and Innkeepers. At its severed, bleeding and butchered heart, SGWKP is actually a relationship drama.
As I watched Red Lights, all I could think of was how much it reminded of other movies, TV shows, and pop culture icons.
Where the otherwise humdrum movie excels, aside from the appropriately dazzling CG and 3D, is in its ironic humor.
Mildly entertaining.
Think of Black Limousine as a mini of the surreal masterwork Mulholland Drive, but with less twists and turns.
movie_title: Black Limousine (The Land of the Astronauts) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There is indeed debauchery, betrayal, power-plays and tragedy as befitting the historical events, but the movie unfurls in a quiet, low-key manner.
Since few watch Rollin for story, I will give a nod to the beauty of the leading ladies, the vast glory of the sets and locations, and the composition of the shots.
[Aside from the fashion and visual] The Dark Knights Rises is a big, beautiful action adventure with heart and soul.
Far more gruesome, and definitely packing more surprise punches than your average, everyday thriller.
The Monitor is one of the better psychological thrillers I've seen in awhile.
If you don't mind style over substance, a bit of the old cat-and-mouse, and you enjoy watching Samuel L. Jackson making people squirm, then hop in, strap up, and hold on.
...a wet blanket of gloom and humorlessness.
All things considered, Remains is reasonably entertaining escapism and is a fun enough apocalyptic fright fest.

Though the cool, insolent stoicism does work for Pattinson as the narcissistic royal-'we' speaking wunderkind, even he can't carry this weighty, wordy dissertation on the burdens of money, fame and power.
I have to give kudos to writer-director Steve Gibson for doing a lot with a little.
Just remember: it's called Piranha 3DD.
When it comes to fashion on film, here's certainly a lot of beauty in Mirror Mirror - I found it a whimsical take on the fairytale of Snow White, the seven dwarfs, and the Evil Queen.
The Wicker Tree is really just campy, sappy suds.
There's a tad of the tawdry, but not enough to satisfy fans of the nunsploitation genre.
While not a showy or stylistic film by any means, Sound of my Voice is impressive.
Unless you're a Whedon buff, wait for DVD.
Boy meets girl. Boy takes girl to graveyard. Boy regrets decision.
To say too much about this taut, and often quite gory, shocking and surprising twisty mystery would spoil the freezer-burn fun.
Overall it's a satisfying, well-made, exciting, technically top-notch and scary movie.
Found footage shakes on a plane.

A sensuous, often suspenseful fable saturated with shades of Sigmund Freud, Lewis Carroll and the Marquis de Sade, the horror comes in the form of actual, traditional fanged vampires who can shape-shift and cause all kinds of deadly mischief.
movie_title: Valerie and Her Week of Wonders (1970)

movie_review_blurb: This is one super-hyped superhero extravaganza that not only meets expectations, but surpasses them.
The dark, gothic underpinnings, cheekily accessorized with sparkly cotton candy glam-era colors, go together like a black velvet cape paired with white vinyl go-go boots.
I can't say Molly is lovely enough to recommend.
Fun, fast-paced.
The Pact is a good one for a late night, home alone.
The movie's clever conceit, cheeky dialogue, and nice cinematography had me hooked immediately.
Bearing in mind that the title of the film translates to 'shadowy, indefinite, or marginal' I leave it up to you to decided whether or not patience is one of your virtues.
It's too bad first time director David Lee Madison can't lay some responsibility on the screenwriter for the horrible script he was saddled with: he's got only himself to blame for this tedious mess.
Unfortunately, as beautifully presented as it is, and no matter how creepily authentic the autopsied and rotting cadavers look, Post Mortem is D.O.A. in the suspense department.

High-concept Hell leans toward stranger-danger slasher horror and amounts to little more than sinister mountain-men hell-bent on killing along the lines of a Wrong Turn movie by way of House of 1000 Corpses.
History may be doomed to repeat itself, but does that mean we have to watch it over and over again?
Somber, noble, and in a way quite beautiful even in its spartan brutality, Haneke has made a movie that is About Something.
While the film is educational, it also packs an emotional and thoughtful punch without ever being manipulative.
Excellent director and investigative reporter Amy Berg had the support of producers Peter Jackson, Fran Walsh, musicians Henry Rollins and Eddie Vedder, all of whom are a part of the presentation.
The best movies encompass not only story, direction, acting, and a certain visceral passion, but striking visuals and amazing audio as well. (I don't ask for much!) Rust and Bone fulfills all.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Think of it as Trekkies for the horror set.
Gripping; there's more suspense and white knuckle tension in this Danish drama than 90% of the outright horror films I saw this year.
Just when I thought it was safe to go back in the water... here comes The Bay.
Whatever your approach to the schoizoid storyline, you're unlikely to ever forget the exhilarating, eruptive cinematic splooge of Holy Motors.
As to expected, ABCs is a mixed bag. It's just too bad there aren't more treats than tricks in this Halloween haul.
It's not outright terrifying, but Here Comes the Devil is subtly scary and well worth a look.
While Silent Hill: Revelation 3D may not allay your hankering for a solid story, it'll definitely satisfy your blood-lust.
Jones is magnificent as a protagonist who's certainly not likable, yet is mysteriously, compulsively, watchable.
While it did feel more like an extended sitcom to me than an actual film, I must say I found it fun.
Bill and Ted meet Dawn of the Dead.
Affectionate, sexy, thought-provoking, devastating, beautiful, bittersweet, life-affirming... Cafe de Flore is all that, and more. See it, listen to it, believe it.

I appreciated the caressing style of the cinematography, fetishizing and sexualizing even the most inanimate and mundane recording equipment and sound-related props, but it's overall hollow and unsatisfying.
Nurmi is sympathetic, likeable, and quite intriguing; she is well worth spending an hour and half with.
The Collection [is] a punchy piece in the pantheon of sequels.
Bigfoot: The Lost Coast Tapes is a decent time-waster.
movie_title: Big Foot: The Lost Coast Tapes (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Is The Possession destined to be a classic? Probably not. But it's well worth a few bucks to see on the big screen, and is certainly one of the better hellish-havoc flicks I've seen in some time.
It's the best successor to Cemetery Man out there, for sure (much better than Dylan Dog!).
The Victim isn't so much a classic-style horror movie - it's more a crime thriller - but fans of the genre will probably enjoy the sex, drugs, and death scenes.
Mysteries and meanings to curl around each other like creeping vines.
movie_title: The Curse of the Cat People (1945)

movie_review_blurb: It's got heart, gore, suspense, and an unusual family-style drama you won't likely forget... and Lola is a terrific character: pretty scary in pink!
If you enjoyed recent scary-but-kid-safe thrillers like Don't Be Afraid of the Dark or Super 8 - albeit toned down for pre-teens - then The Hole is definitely worth a peek.
Livid is almost all allegory, mood, style, flourish, freak-out and suspense.
Dialogue's decent, but for every smart quip there are 10 insipid expletives.
I highly recommend Dredd for what it is: a super-violent, well thought-out, effective thriller and action film that's flawlessly cast and has several supreme scenarios of cat-and-mouse.
House at the End of the Street is what it is: a teenage version of Fatal Attraction (1987) with a dash of The Collector (1965).
movie_title: House at the End of the Street (2012)

movie_review_blurb: I loved it, but beware: It is not a scary movie, it's a paranormal romance and it's essentially about a father/daughter relationship.
Lee Daniels, by way of Tennessee Williams doing The Twist with Russ Meyer, does it up right in this garishly glorious period piece of trailer-trash operatic, Southern gothic noir.
[Bousman fans:] It's not quite up to Saw and Mother's Day levels in gut wrenching horror, but The Barrens is a good mix of supernatural and visceral.
Looper is one of the few modern-day character-motivated science fiction films to [also] succeed on levels of action and suspense.
Come Die with Me is the tagline for Airborne, which is clever. Too bad the rest of the movie is not. This one's got a British accent, and not much else.
Perfectly poised for a Halloween release, I daresay Frankenweenie is an instant classic.
The goriest Buddhist serial killer comedy I have ever seen.
Based on the best-selling memoir of the same name, this funny, irreverent, poignant, fast-paced and fun flick is well worth the investment.
This is one you'll want to hustle to see on the big screen.
It's worth a look for the acting and the accoutrements.
Though its theme is hardly a happy subject, this thought-provoking Danish drama on the false accusation of child abuse is nonetheless extra-highly recommended
It's a 'feel good movie' but Hidden Figures is never schmaltzy and is doesn't gloss over the weighty issues.
If you're a fan of the original 1975 movie, you will appreciate the gung-ho spirit with which Death Race 2050 is presented.
I dare you to look away.
There's a very positive message about not judging books by their covers.
Funniest Caped Crusader ever!
The Great Wall proudly presents a barrage of battles you might want to see for the 3D... but there is nothing scary or striking about the movie itself.
Surrender to the macabre insanity and take a dive into those deep waters...
The Id is a thought-provoking psychological chiller that's well worth a look... into the abyss!
Rock Dog shares a more similar theme to Zootopia: follow your dreams no matter of the odds.
Delightfully Disney!

There's an interesting cross-section of codes of morality and rationale from the various unwilling participants in the experiment, proving plenty of food for thought and a few things to discuss with friends (and coworkers) after the end credits fade.
Everlasting tells a compelling story with beautiful visuals.
Don't go in expecting another Finding Dory or Inside Out - it's no deeper than Boss Baby's razor-thin briefcase.
While it's a slow burn, One of Us does come to a fiery close, and at a tight 86 minutes it never wears out its welcome.
Fate of the Furious is cinematic fast food but for action-oriented teens, gearheads, or those who are simply fans of the franchise, it's worth taking a spin.
Just because the stories shown are tried and true doesn't mean they're any less spectacular or gripping.
So exciting you might wonder if your knuckles could get any whiter.
Redundant, slim storyline.
Like they did in the golden era of cinema; slip into a dark movie theater and lose yourself in this impossible, irresistible world.
Elle feels like a few different movies, but it does present an intriguing question of what consent really means and how past and present experiences shape the mind, body and soul.
If you're in the mood for a thriller with a little action and you want to see Blake Lively in a bikini, then maybe The Shallows is worth an hour and a half of your time.
There's a lot of predictable animal humor, but there are also several harrowing moments of nail-biting suspense.
This is the kind of movie that really gets audiences alternating between hiding their faces in their hands to outright applause.
I recommend this one only for die-hard fans of killer kids horror.
The Little Prince is a fond tribute, true to its source material and original unto itself.
Deftly directed by Fede Alvarez, Don't Breathe hits the ground running and never slows to take a breath.
It's definitely in a class of its own and one of the more unique kids' stories out right now.
It's as flawless a horror film -- and specifically a monster movie -- you're likely to find in this or any other year.
The Girl on the Train review says it misses the boat by not embracing the over-the-top potboiler parody it could have been, instead opting for Lifetime movie-of-the week blandness.
Dead Awake is a dream come true for fans of modern horror with a classic look and feel.
Ouija: Origin of Evil succeeds on many levels.

If you're in search of an original horror film, and you are a fan of the slower, more hypnotic horror of the 70s - and you don't mind a lack of blood and guts - then The Butterfly Room is definitely one for your collection.
The Shelter is enjoyable, well made and ably acted. It is definitely worth a look for fans of psychological slow burns.
Aside from the dazzling eye-candy, this is a pretty thought-provoking movie.
Blood Trails does not blaze any new trails, but it's got style, substance, and scares.

In the plus column, Arrival feels like a dreamily updated version of 1951's The Day the Earth Stood Still. On the negative side, there's not enough excitement or revelation to justify its two-hour runtime.
Phantasm: Ravager is not the place to start with the series (noobs beware), but it's a helluva way to end it.
Alien: Covenant is cruel and scary - it's a hard R, and the suspense levels are off the charts. The monsters ... are believable and terrifying.
While there is an underlying existential anxiety to the whole thing, there's not enough pizzazz to either the visuals or the dialogue to make It Comes at Night worth going to see in the theater.
The Mummy is overall a fun movie, doing what it says it's going to do: mildly entertain. But in the end, it's just "the meh-my."

While the story behind the curious little monkey who has captivated readers for nearly a century is interesting, the real takeaway from Monkey Business is illustrating what can be accomplished with perseverance, talent, and true love.
movie_title: Monkey Business: The Adventures of Curious George's Creators (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Roman J. Israel, Esq., has its moments - thanks mostly to the ever-watchable Washington - but it's heavy-handed in its message.
I wanted to see the classic tale of hidden identity I was promised, not a retread of Stand and Deliver.
The Shape of Water is a dreamlike, pulpy adult fairytale that dances on the surface of reality while remaining true to the auteur's vision.
Feel-good magic!
Pooh isn't the only thing that's stuffy in Goodbye Christopher Robin...
Heartfelt, and easy to love.
Leap! is an absolutely delightful, fun, and at times heartbreaking film that's perfect for girls.
The Disaster Artist has broad appeal because it's not just about making a movie, it's about believing in yourself against all odds.
It's somewhat interesting to witness the events that led to one of the most famous speeches of the 20th century, but not 2 hours, 5-minutes worth of interesting.
Unfortunately, the structure is a mess. It feels like a series of scenarios strung together, without cohesive light at the end of the tunnel.
First and foremost, The Greatest Showman is a musical reverie - an ode to dreams - not a biopic.
It's a movie I admire more than I like.
Folks coming in fresh [not having seen the original], and casual horror fans, will more than likely enjoy it.
Aside from the quick setup introducing the targets, The Strangers: Prey at Night really is a nonstop thrill ride... I was breathless from start to finish.
While the extravaganza film adaptation of the beloved novel has magic in it, it most certainly is not magical.
Shows Tonya was a fighter, and she still is.
The LEGO Ninjago Movie is almost as fun and irreverent as the previous installments in this click-together build-a-world of corporate animation.
When all is said and done, it's Radcliffe who makes you care about how it all turns out. He's a truly fine actor.
It's more by-the-numbers action than grab-you horror. Jigsaw's screenwriters don't have the guts to push beyond the boundaries.
Camera Obscura is more psychological thriller than horror -- in fact, it's not scary at all but there are enough moments of suspense and mystery to make it worth your while.
While the movie is not perfect ... 47 Meters Down should please folks who want to see a suspenseful, simple story about survival against all odds.
It's definitely a worthy entry -- if not one of the best -- in the Conjuring universe of horror... Annabelle: Creation should be seen late at night, in the dark.
While The Blackcoat's Daughter is intriguing and seductive at the start, in the end it doesn't quite live up to the insinuations it made in the beginning.
While I didn't love Be Afraid - it retreads a lot of overly-familiar ground - I liked it. It's worth a look, especially if you're partial to horror nightmares.

I just can't recommend you rush to the theater to see it. This movie feels like a practice run. Hopefully the next collaboration between Dillard and Blumhouse - a "survival horror" called Sweetheart - will be better.
Although I was able to see where every turn was headed, thanks to the fine filmmaking and able acting, I didn't mind; I was content to just go along for the ride.
Snappy, acerbic script by Lee Ross is augmented by first time director Kai Ephron's pathos for his characters and situations.
Overall, Killing Ground is a solid thriller and a good one to watch home alone in the dark.

While the account is not terribly original, [Alexandre] Bustillo and [Julien] Maury bring a joie de mort giddiness to Leatherface. It's great to see their French New Wave/splatterpunk sensibilities come alive once again...
They say necessity is the mother of invention. Well, writer-director Darren Aronofsky's mother! certainly is inventive.
Anyone who loves the history of fashion - the doc presents archival video from swinging London to gritty 1980s Paris, and everyplace in-between - will enjoy aspects of this film.
movie_title: Manolo, The Boy Who Made Shoes For Lizards (2017)

movie_review_blurb: American Made does everything it should: it educates and it entertains.
An existential sci-fi opus.
The script is quite clever ... Happy Death Day is one of the best horror-comedies to come out in some time ... it's a whole lot of fun.
[T]here's no horror or suspense to the proceedings at all. In fact, each successive appearance of the silly snowman is just plain funny...
Truly unsettling, genuinely provocative.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Abattoir offers a smart story, compelling performances, and a great blend of talent and technique.
When it comes to the sheer artistry of filmmaking, it's an astounding, jaw-dropping feat of furious beauty.
The Neon Demon is gushing with gory glam and oozing beautiful baroque patina from its every pore.
A long, strange trip well worth taking. Crank it up!

Like a lush Ingmar Bergman chamber piece with a touch Jess Franco style sensuality, one could say The Duke of Burgundy is a kinky cross between the seminal S&M sendup Secretary and the most dazzling homage to giallo in recent years, Amer.
One of the best horror movies to come along in years.
It's reminiscent of other recent child-abduction and exploitation films such as Prisoners and The Frozen Ground, but there's something just a little twistedly different that sets it apart.
The movie's not all bad. It's just a bit bland.
On a scale of one to Gigli, Jennifer Lopez's latest cinematic sortie is off the charts.
Hip to all the ins and outs of grue and gore [Everly] spares not a single blood-drop.
I don't expect reinvention of the wheel, as long as a movie rolls along well enough. And this one does.
In true 80s throwback fashion, coupled with a hip, sleek and modern look, Wolves is the perfect hybrid between The Howling and Hemlock Grove.
While Cut Bank has its clever moments, funny running gags, and a few shocking death scenes, it's just too expository and derivative; what's more, it takes itself far too seriously.

Ex Machina is what I call an existential horror movie. It feels as visceral as anything created by the Crichtons, Spielbergs, and Scotts of an era gone by, but it's got a contemporary, current, and forward-thinking propulsion to it.
I daresay Furious 7 is best of the lot since the original. Fasten your seatbelts, suspend your disbelief, and enjoy the ride!
Understated in spite of its sensational subject matter, it's a well-made if somewhat humdrum movie.

I recommend Dial A Prayer for its actors - Snow is well-cast, Macy is of course golden in every single thing he does, and the supporting cast is likeable - and a story that's got a good message yet is not overly preachy in delivering it.
While it's not a flawless fright flick, Unfriended gives us a good gimmick as byte-sized horror that's easy to 'like' before moving onto the next distraction.
The Water Diviner comes up dry.
If you're in the mood for a talky little neo-noir potboiler, 3 Holes and Smoking Gun is just the ticket.
While one can certainly see Penn's attraction to a globe-trotting, gun-toting, hard-loving role such as this, one also can't help but wonder how it all falls so flat.
The screenplay falls short, making what might have been an instant classic into something more like instant gratification before the next Netflix click claims our wandering attention.
Think: Downton Abbey meets The Knick.
As a mood piece, the film captures the essence of a time in music history quite beautifully.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Violent beyond belief, bloody and yet a bloody-good time, Raze is a fun one for fans of hard action and well-choreographed bare-knuckle fight scenes.
RoboCop is worth a look on the big screen for the visual spectacle, but for the visceral satire you're better off revisiting the original.
... it'll please a lot of fans.
The ending peters out a bit, but if you enjoy a little sadistic horror with a touch of humor, then 13 Sins is a fun enough time waster.
Though The Quiet Ones does not quite work as a throwback to Hammer's heyday, it does, however, serve its purpose as a decent time-waster.
If you're a sucker for singing and slashing, you're likely to like Stage Fright.
Adds fresh blood to the proceedings yet stays true to the formula of the original.
But if you're looking for just a quick, fun, and forgettable vampire bite, then Dracula Untold doesn't disappoint.
Joy Ride 3 is a serviceable enough gore fest and the actors are all up to par.
But if you're a sucker for the subject matter, you'll probably want to check it out anyway.
A good thriller for a dark night of Netflixing.
There are clichs, shameless emotion manipulation and cardboard cutout characters; but the moments of suspense and the renderings of relentless killer storms are at times truly breathtaking.
A lot of fun.
The movie is overly long, and certainly overly-violent in contrast to its sometimes preachy do-right earnestness, but it's worth a look.
While Horns is a mixed bag - tonally, it can't quite decide if it's fable or grit - the flick's fine.
Comedic elements aside, Housebound succeeds as a horror film - it's got some great jump-scares, a compelling plot-twisty mystery, and oh yes: plenty of gore.
A nice throwback to old school suspensers like Altered States and Brainscan.

Despite the frenetic pace of Mad Max: Fury Road and its massive set-pieces, gobsmack-nonstop action and violence, insane costuming, and its bombastic soundtrack, there is a story and there is character development.
It's an exciting movie, a fun romp that's well acted and nicely paced.

Perhaps even more egregious than its inherently repulsive premise is the fact that The Human Centipede 3: The Final Sequence is cinematically constipated... nothing happens for a long, long time; and when it does, it's just crap.
I enjoyed The Funhouse Massacre and would watch it again; it's a good addition to the Halloween-themed canon. The title says it all: fun and massacre.
The characters are not only unlikable, passive-aggressive jerks, they are boring and predictable to boot. Add to that stunningly stupid dialogue, and you're in for a shallow dive indeed.
Good movie, bad title.
When it comes to Krampus, you'd better watch out.
It's like a cinematic listicle. In other words, there's an awful lot going on in The Big Short!
It's not perfect, but Dark is one of the better arty indies I've seen in some time.
I was somewhat dissatisfied with the ending, but that sort of thing is subjective, and I encourage everyone to watch The Abandoned to judge for themselves.
I already knew a lot about Janis Joplin, but that doesn't mean I didn't learn something - and, I was deeply moved by its inevitable end.
45 Years is not story-driven, it's character-driven - and how exquisitely nuanced these people are!
The dialogue is brisk, as are the twists and turns.
Solace has all the stuff I love. But not all the stuff everybody loves. It's a mixed bag.
Straddles the line between tradition and terror, fidelity to the source, forging new territory, and showing societal roles filled by brain-sucking zombies - with admirable aplomb.
The Coen Brothers have done it again - made an ensemble crime caper comedy that's pure tinsel town gold!
Oh, boy - is he fresh! Chances are you're going to love this well-written, witty, funny, romantic, sexy, silly, action packed, wild ride. I sure did!
It's a drama, it's a thriller, horror, sci-fi and mystery all in one.
It's intriguing enough to turn into a feature.
It's best to wait for home viewing on this one.
I like how Morely juxtaposes urban life with inner life, and how the two don't always intersect.
While I think it's a worthwhile doc, it runs too long and paints a rather (unintended, I believe) poor portrait of McQueen.
movie_title: Steve McQueen: The Man & Le Mans (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Not only is the story engrossing - and true! - sometimes upsetting, and always informative, but it's also funny.

...both lovely, and looooooong.
The blend of top-notch CGI, realism, stunts, and breakneck pace keep all the exploding balls in the air, and the 3D is blissfully easy on the eyes.
Strangerland is presented through a prism of womanly wantoness juxtaposed with a mother's pain and fear.

The story moves right along, and the characters are fun.
It's a wild ride with a few thrills along the way.

The actors are good (especially Walsh, who was one of my favorites in last year's Paranormal Activity: The Marked Ones), the story sails right along at a brisk clip that's just right for its 89-minute running time, and there's even a romantic subplot.
Treat!

Looking for a good horror movie to watch this Halloween? Check out Crimson Peak.

Not since Carrie has the prom been this much bloody fun!
I was entertained for all the wrong reasons.
Deliciously over-the-top and delightfully deranged.

movie_review_blurb: If you love the '70s, and especially if you're a fan of sexploitation comedies like The Happy Hooker or today's me-generation throwbacks like CBS's Swingtown, then you absolutely cannot miss seeing Viva.

movie_review_blurb: The class ring of horror/comedies.

Spiral is an interesting experiment in the evocation of things that do not actually exist, and it succeeds with sizzle.
One of best in the heist genre I've seen in some time.

Boring gate.

Hats off to Baghead.
This time, the movie theater is a trap.

movie_review_blurb: Routine surgery.
The dialogue is laugh-out-loud hilarious at times, and you've gotta love the dated tunes and far-out fashions.
Madonna's got her Godard down!

Absolutely adorable and enormously entertaining.
There are a few funny things that make this Mod curio worth one look.

Eight stories... and none of them good.
While I can't in good conscious recommend Dark Reel even as a rental, it might be worth a look on late-night TV for insomniac fans of the cast and admirers of whacky Hollywood send-ups.
I'd love to ramble on about Tom Atkins, to recount all the awesome death scenes, cool homages to the original and such, but this remake is definitely one best seen for yourself (twice!).
...one of the best genre films of the past few years!
At his most placid, JT Petty can make Terrence Malick look like Guy Ritchie. But when he's not going full-'bore', his quiet, creepy brand of terror works on several levels.
Carpenter and Harris are able to pull off the whole charade with impressive energy and convincing bursts of sheer terror during some very long, uncut takes.
When it comes to this giallo, mood, style, and hyperbole trump and trample substance and meaning.

It was all I could do to watch the whole thing till the end - and I'm sorry for that, because there is so much to like about the film, [aside from the lax editing].
While the slight story and gore factor rate low, the Argento style is in full flourish. ... Four Flies on Grey Velvet is worthy of all the nostalgic buzz.

Competent, but not a prizewinner.
Dawn grits her teeth.
Not at all Butchered.
Timewaster.
If you have a high tolerance for less-than-B flicks, you might find Mammoth worth a look. If not, then you're better off with a back-to-back movie marathon of Dumbo, Alien, and Night At The Museum.

For horror, suspense and dark fantasy fans wondering about the monstrous Davy Jones, the legendary Kracken, and phantomly pirates - they're all here, but the story is really more about the end of an era.

movie_review_blurb: A competent curio reimagining of the silent-era classic.
A sinful cinematic experience for fans of classy, canny killers like Hannibal Lecter, Patrick Bateman, and Dexter Morgan.

The story falls flat.

movie_review_blurb: Reminiscent of scary/spacey dramas like 2001: A Space Odyssey, Solaris, and Alien, this flick doesn't break any new ground. However, the acting is beyond reproach and the characters are as textured and layered as in any fully-realized drama.

The plot mirrors a good, old-fashioned ghost story complete with curses!

Go stand in the corner, Dark Corners!

Works like a charm!

I have got to hand it to Darabont for coming up with one of the most definitive, unforgettable climaxes in horror movie history. It's worth the price of admission, alone.

Intelligent, absorbing, and exceedingly well-acted.

This is one call you should definitely miss.
Although it's quite grimy and gritty, there is still an over-glossed pop-culture feel to the Watchmen movie... it worked for me.

Arresting!

One M1ssed Call meets Final Destination in this formulaic but fun gore-fest. In case you are wondering, there are chains. And letters. [it] is about as subtle as a sledgehammer, but that works in this mushy, gushy milieu.
Bloated with exposition and exaggerated effects, by the time the climax comes you've lost all devotion. But...! Hopkins is excellent as Father Lucas.
I enjoyed Paranormal Activity 2 and I'd recommend it even if you weren't a fan of the first.

As a critic I had some issues, but as a moviegoer, I was ensconced in every moment. Deft direction (and misdirection), keeps the tension ratchet-tight.

It's all so tongue-in-cheek... serious horror fans probably won't get it, but those who love the grindhouse will be all over this flick, 3D glasses and all.

A love letter to [director] James Wan's favorite movie, Poltergeist, this spooky story follows a young couple and their children into a new home... and into the pit of darkness when an evil presence makes its insidious intentions known.
A confusing cache of characters populate this underwritten story - I had trouble following the threads, but did enjoy the exploding heads.
Not really a horror film (blood-slurping notwithstanding), Limitless is more a suspense-thriller that should appeal to fans of tension and adrenaline.

While the material is bleak as hell, the players add some depth and dimension to their characters and one can see the makeup and f/x crew was working overtime to deliver the most realistic, gruesome death scenes possible.

movie_review_blurb: For what it is, Saw 7 is serviceable.

Though very well-acted, the story collapses under the weight of its own disjointed melancholia.

Actually, In Time's not that bad. It's just not that good, either.

I wanted more pizzazz and deeper, more nuanced characterizations from Fincher and co., but for those who have no context regarding pervious Larsson presentations this story-driven procedural may be well be good enough.

movie_review_blurb: I liked it well enough, up until the sucker-punch ending.

Lea Thompson and John Shea sit down 'My Dinner With Andre' style and chew the fat about love, life, longing and letting go, in this unexpectedly poignant, often wryly humorous, drama.
Director Ti West is carving quite a niche for himself by exploring horror genres popularized by others by stripping them down to the varnish and actually deglamorizing them. It's effective.

While his name isn't as instantly accessible as his costars, Mark Kelly carries this movie from beginning to end and holds his own well against perhaps more charismatic but ultimately less-deep performances.

Kickin' It Old Skool aspires to be Big with break dancing, but it falls flat on its spinning head. Even the break dancing gets tired fast, making the film even more tedious to get through.
Paris Je T'aime is a poignant and ultimately rewarding experience. It offers something for everyone, and provides an insightful, multi-cultural look at the City of Lights.

Shrek the Third is the X-Men: The Last Stand of Shrek movies: overstuffed with characters, short and fast-paced, and overdone just enough to convince some that it's time for the series to take a rest.
Thanks to its direction, cast and political subtext, 28 Weeks Later is a horror sequel that's actually worth seeing and improves upon (in some areas) its predecessor.

Overall, though, Fay Grim only occasionally connects with the viewer. It is a film so caught up in its own cleverness and cheekiness that -- despite the solid work by its cast -- it forgets to make you truly care about its characters.
The Invisible plays like a self-indulgent adolescent wish-fulfillment fantasy.
Lucky You is a decent and often engaging character study that deserved more respect from critics and the studio than it received.

While Next has a few fun and inventive moments sprinkled throughout, mostly revolving around the use of Cris' power, it collapses into an exhausting litany of action movie clichs before exposing itself as a total mindjob in the end.
Despite its slew of genre cliches, Shooter works in fits and starts as a valentine to a simpler era in action films.
Fracture has some involving moments and bright ideas, but it's such a pedestrian execution that it could have just as easily been made as a TV movie with Mark-Paul Gosselaar and Kelsey Grammer.
For all its flaws, Pathfinder is a unique little action film.
While Perfect Stranger had its moments and wisely made its characters less than perfect, it was a pedestrian yarn better suited for the small screen than the silver one.
If The Reaping had been sown with fresher ideas, you might actually care if the devil went down to Georgia, er, Louisiana.
The Lookout makes it a solid and entertaining throwback to the crime thrillers of yesteryear.
Despite its shortcomings, Pride proves to be an effective feel-good sports drama.
Despite its attempt at being well-meaning family genre fare a la E.T., The Last Mimzy simply collapses under the considerable weight of its many bewildering plot elements.
Performances by Sandler and Cheadle give the film enough of what it needs in order to recommend it.

The propagandistic Maxed Out is ultimately undermined by the fact that, as vile as many of its corporate interviewees seem, its everyman subjects are often just as culpable in creating and perpetuating the whole mess.
I Think I Love My Wife doesn't seem to know which choice to embrace (comedy or drama) and ends up being a hit-and-miss affair.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Bug is more cerebral than visceral so those expecting a more traditional chiller may be disappointed. But for those interested in a creepy character study, this Bug has bite.

Vacancy may not be the most wholly original thriller but it has some heart to it and is directed with gritty, old school style by Nimrd Antal. Coupled with the good work done by the leads, Vacancy is worth checking into.

Besson excels at stories about rough characters who are saved through their relationship with a more civilized character (as in The Professional and La Femme Nikita). Angel-A adheres to that paradigm, but it also has more soul, humor and warmth than those

John Moore's Omen still delivers some good scares here and there, and it is one of the better entries in the recent spate of horror remakes, but not even the Anti-Christ can catch lightning in a bottle twice.

The humor is sophisticated enough for adults to enjoy and, while there's plenty of cool and cute stuff for the kids, we are thankfully spared any juvenile, obnoxious musical sequences with wisecracking animals bursting into song.
Tears of the Black Tiger ultimately works best as an exercise in cinematic style, making it not only a quirky little nostalgia trip but a noteworthy cult flick worth checking out.
movie_title: Fah talai jone (Tears of the Black Tiger) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Overall, fans of this type of horror film might appreciate See No Evil for the exploitation flick that it is but others will be let down as they will have seen it all before.
Like the X-Men film series itself, it got more right than it did wrong...
While Waist Deep offers precious little that hasn't been seen before, its energy, wit, effective lead performances and taut direction save this old-fashioned B-movie...
Monster House is arguably the best family film so far this summer.
For those seeking an intense, seductive and gritty crime drama, Miami Vice delivers the goods.
Solid, respectful and moving.
What elevates Crank above other high-concept action fare, though, is its politically incorrect sense of humor and overall bent sensibility.
Hollywoodland was clearly a labor of love, and it succeeds in making people not only remember who George Reeves was but to see him as something more than an actor in a cape.
Unfortunately, rather than being his comeback film, The Black Dahlia is just the latest in a long line of disappointments from De Palma.
Recycles every mentor/student and military movie clich in the proverbial book yet it does so effectively and with enough heart to prove see-worthy.
The Last King of Scotland belongs to Forest Whitaker. He is the key to making this Faustian bargain work.
A surprisingly amusing -- albeit formulaic -- piece of fluff.
The Queen rules. It is among the best films of the year. It has humor, pathos, intelligence and intrigue. Fully realized characters engage us from start to finish.
Writer-director Barry Levinson had better fortune (and results) with the prescient Wag the Dog than he does with his latest political satire, the uneven and uninvolving Man of the Year.
Its choppy pacing, thumbnail characterizations and overall smallness makes Infamous feel more like a very good HBO telepic rather than a big-screen endeavor.

Overlong and overdone, Running With Scissors strives to be a Wes Anderson-esque satire, but often feels like a string of skits held together by a compelling premise. This film is a perfect example of a movie whose parts are greater than its whole.
Through its use of archival news footage and contemporary interviews, Cocaine Cowboys proves to be an intoxicating exploration of Miami, the '80s cocaine trade and those who saw it all happen.

It is indeed ironic that a film that is often so good at making one suspend their disbelief still can't generate a true emotional response in the end. Despite its shortcomings, Death of a President is an interesting and provocative work that merits
Ghost Rider fails for the same reason every bad movie does: poor storytelling and bad acting.
First Snow is a small film that deserves to find a big audience.
DOA is a bad, cheesy and cheap production that nevertheless has enough goofy appeal to warrant watching with your buddies...
Far more entertaining and ambitious than its predecessor, Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer is a surprisingly effective summer movie and a huge improvement over the lackluster 2005 original.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Mixing history, sword & sorcery and science-fiction, Day Watch is overstuffed with gimmicks, making it a noisy but nifty-looking mess. Although wall-to-wall action, only a few sequences -- such as the climactic hotel showdown between the forces of Light a
The Host is a decent little monster movie that fans of the genre should enjoy.

The first of the young Harry Potter stars to land a leading role outside of the blockbuster franchise, Rupert Grint shows he has what it takes to enjoy an acting career post-Hogwarts in the engaging coming-of-age dramedy Driving Lessons.

Amazing Grace thoughtfully explores the issue of slavery without sermonizing or losing sight of the fact that modern audiences still need to connect with relatable characters no matter how important the subject matter.
Sleuth succeeds as a gripping, character-driven thriller.
It isn't just another movie about the momentous events of the '60s, but rather a valentine to the era's artistic and idealistic spirit as symbolized by the music of The Beatles.

The parts are ultimately greater than the whole in the case of Good Luck Chuck, with the overall chemistry between Cook and Alba proving more memorable than any particular joke or sequence. You may mildly enjoy Chuck as you're watching it, but the film wi
. As serious and cerebral as The Kingdom is, it's content with being a "movie" rather than a "film" and proves that a studio production doesn't have to be trite in order to be enjoyable.
The Dark is Rising is yet another lackluster and derivative entry in the overstuffed genre of youth-oriented fantasy films.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: If you like your history lessons loud and garish, bombastic and bloody, then Elizabeth: The Golden Age is for you.
Gray's characters are weighty and dimensional enough to allow the viewer to overlook the generic nature of the story.
Director Slade has fashioned a horror film that, for all its narrative shortcomings, succeeds at what it set out to do: make vampires scary again and terrify audiences doing it.
A morality play disguised as a murder-mystery, Gone Baby Gone asks some powerful questions about the price to be paid for doing the right thing and what the proverbial right thing even means.
A thoughtful and often compelling drama about grief, anger and revenge...
There are a few fleeting moments where you may find yourself chuckling, but it's more out of pity than pleasure.
The movie truly is about an "American Gangster;" it's a business movie about unbridled capitalism that's been dressed up as the highbrow answer to Superfly.
Lions for Lambs simply isn't fresh or courageous enough to make an impact let alone a difference.
Atonement is one of the best and most powerful films of 2007 and should be well rewarded come Oscar time.
It's deplorable that these two stars have been reduced to appearing in such garbage.
One of the year's very best films.
Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story may have its share of flat spots, but it's also a very canny send-up of the tried-and-true genre of showbiz biopics.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Water Horse's fluctuation between wholesome kiddie flick, complete with silly humor, and dark fantasy/coming-of-age drama ultimately proves too unwieldy for the filmmakers to handle, causing the film to sink under the weight of all its well-meaning bu
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Honeydripper is a decent but lesser entry in the unique and praiseworthy oeuvre of John Sayles, a maverick filmmaker who has done more to showcase America, its pros and cons, and diversity than any other filmmaker alive.

Inane comedies can be fun when done well, but bad inane comedies are simply embarrassing. You feel pity for the actors making fools of themselves, and flabbergasted that a studio probably passed on making so many other more worthy projects instead.
For all its flaws, Zohan remains a tolerable if inane piece of entertainment that scores points for trying...
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Good to have you back, 007.
While it is far too long, especially in the home stretch, The Astronaut Farmer is a heartwarming and fun story about the tenacity it takes to see a dream through.
Jones could win Best Actor...
Eastern Promises is a compelling drama about the collision of conscience and criminality. Chalk up another win for David Cronenberg.
Although The Savages is a better film for not being a cloying, schmaltzy tear-jerker, that doesn't mean that it's a movie you will necessarily enjoy.
As involving and heartwarming as The Jane Austen Book Club is, it's also far too much of a gimmick for its own good.
The Number 23 is Schumacher's first stab at a scary movie, the end result just doesn't quite add up.

Of all the many films about Jesse James, Andrew Dominik's epic may not end up ranking as the most popular or the best film on the subject but it will certainly, flaws and all, be regarded as the most intriguing and ambitious take on the man and his myth.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: General audiences might find the film too cerebral or talky, but it was refreshing to finally see a spy film that wasn't trying to be Bourne again.
The problem with The Messengers is that it simply doesn't offer up much of anything new.
A solid but formulaic throwback.
Smokin' Aces isn't the most original endeavor, but it has enough wit, action and dramatic weight to carve out its own rightful place of honor in the crime film genre.
The Dead Girl segues from one turgidly-paced, soul-crushing sequence to another with very little reason to continue watching.
Black Christmas works best as a campy deconstruction of the genre than it does as a horror film.
Director Alfonso Cuarn's stunning big-screen version of the P.D. James novel Children of Men is one of the best pictures of 2006.
Live Free or Die Hard may be overblown and cartoonish, but it's also a helluva lot of fun and may become the surprise hit of the summer.
Despite its shortcomings, Chuck and Larry should satiate the modest tastes of the run-of the-mill viewer who simply wants some trite entertainment and easy laughs to pass the time with.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: While this new Hitcher has its moments, it just doesn't make for as scary or interesting a ride as its predecessor.

Although Superbad often runs the risk of being a one-note joke, there's still enough heart to the story and appealing characters to highly recommend it. Superbad certainly isn't on par with other recent Apatow productions such as Knocked Up and The 40 Yea
A kick-ass action film, as well as a vastly entertaining movie that proves that popcorn flicks don't have to be dumb, shallow or contemporary to be enjoyed.
The story ultimately devolves into a standard "monster in the house" thriller about a woman in peril.
The Nines is imaginative and intriguing, but not enough so to keep from alienating some viewers who will be bewildered by the film's existential overtones.
It's a shame that a movie with so many genuinely funny and talented people involved wasn't better.
Because it focuses on characters and relationships rather than merely the more sensational aspects of the story, Resurrecting the Champ delivers a knock-out.
Illegal Tender has its moments -- including the aforementioned shootout involving Millie -- but it is ultimately undone by the litany of genre cliches it embraces.

Becoming Jane may fudge the facts, but it finds the more compelling emotional truth.
This werewolf flick is all bark and no bite.
Death Sentence is a better film than many might expect and also delivers several good doses of action for fans of shoot 'em-ups.
