An excruciatingly challenging and disquieting watch, that will move and compel you in equal measure.
Meyers latest endeavour has it's heart in completely the right place, with not an ounce of cynicism anywhere to be found.

There are times in Pan when you are left in awe of what you are seeing, with some remarkable visuals, and the occasional scene that will have you completely mesmerised. But regrettably such moments are few and far between.
Manages to surprise and engage the viewer in a way you may not have expected.
Roberts has instantly established a creative, resourceful vision as a filmmaker, with an aptitude for presenting a story in a unique way, and forming an indelible atmosphere in the process.
Using such a tired, commonly flawed concept with the found footage angle, Shyamalan doesn't do anything to justify taking such a hackneyed approach.
A disengaging thriller that struggles to compel the viewer, telling a unique, real-life story in an all too generic fashion.
Despite any initial apprehensions, by the close of play it's difficult to have not become immersed, and emotionally attached to this absorbing tale.
Still marks a creatively inclined project for Simon Blake, who cannot be faulted for his aptitude for ingenuity, with a palpable attempt to be experimental in his means of storytelling.
When posing the question of whether we need a new Transporter movie in our lives, it becomes clear only moments in to this generic endeavour, that the answer is regrettably, a big fat no.
The line between what is considered entertaining, and what is downright absurd is also a rather thin one.
Undoubtedly jovial in parts, with a playful, adventurous tone, what transpires is a picture that's darkly absurd.
It's of great commendation to Oram that he's created something so unorthodox and avant-garde amidst a cinematic landscape palpably devoid of originality.
Revels in the meta approach, as art imitates life, imitating art. Or something like that.
What would you do if you could absolutely anything? Well, choosing to go back in time 90 minutes and see something else would be rather high up on the agenda.
It's a truly accomplished study of his demise, a sad portrait of his life.
In Powley we have a true star in the making.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A film that is devoid of any true focus, not quite sure if it's attempting to be a stylistic offering in the same mould as Bronson, or be naturalistic and gritty.
It's difficult to comprehend quite why this stellar cast all signed up to this distinctively lacklustre project.
This tongue-in-cheek endeavour is playful in its approach, never earnest enough to a point where it's unbearable.
The story is remarkable and profound, however the way the tale has been presented and told is too cliched, devaluing the poignancy attached to this narrative.
Though the comedy is surrealist in parts, and exaggerated in others, this remains an intimate study of one man getting all of his affairs in order.
A candid, and painfully honest look into the life of the luminary, iconic Nina Simone.
Grounded by the romantic narrative that exists, Project Almanac finds a strand of intimacy amidst the grandiose elements, in a surprisingly sincere fashion.
Condon does a fine job humanising an otherwise mythical figure, catching up with him as an elderly gentleman, and exploring the vulnerability and physical restraints that come with that.
The immensely talented Haigh has displayed an aptitude for portraying the nuances and subtleties of love, in a truly moving, and tremendously naturalistic drama.
Following rather forgettable performances from James Franco in both Queen of the Desert and Every Thing Will Be Fine - also both showing at Berlinale - this is one of his career's finest.

Having penned various episodes for both Mad Men and The Sopranos, what Weiner manages to squeeze into an entire season he's attempted to fit into almost two hours of cinema with this particular endeavour.
Such is the affable tone and vivacious, good-natured spirit of this charming piece of cinema, that you are able to look past any flaws, and enjoy this for what it is.
An absorbing insight into the life of one of the industry's mot renowned, and elusive stars.
Coherence is, at times, somewhat incoherent, but always on the right side of farcicality.
There is no denying that Fifty Shades, for the most part, is nonsensical and absurd, but it's undoubtedly good fun.
Given the expectations of the director and the stellar cast collated, an unwelcome sense of dissatisfaction is the final, longest-lasting sentiment.
There's a rhythm to Philibert's work, a tangible linearity - as he knows how to take every day life and illuminate it, find the subtleties, the nuances for us to appreciate and to resonate with.
This film is vying to appeal to a certain audience, and it's likely that both children and teenagers will adhere to this animation tremendously.
An unashamedly and unrelentingly enjoyable piece makes for immensely entertaining cinema.
Multi-faceted and nuanced, each with so many subtleties and complexities Ex_Machina is a film bursting with ideas.
Falls short thanks to its contrived banality, too concerned with matching the exploits of the preceding endeavour than being unique and inventive in its own right.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Not an idealistic, all flowers and cuddles ordeal - it's a veritable depiction of true love, and companionship.

The eerie music and abstract, experimental approach to storytelling creates a disquieting ambiance which emanates off the screen, turning what could effectively be a light tale, into something that seems so sinister.

While requiring little effort to get immersed in this tale, such is the strength of this compelling story - if there is one thing to take away from proceedings, it's that it is worth catching this in its original, more authentic form.
An enchanting picture that is grounded by its distinct profundity.
Given the themes explored, and the potential in the enchantment coming to an abrupt end - this picture should be more poignant and heartfelt than what transpires.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Though the simplicity of this narrative, and the restricted, confined setting is a unique selling point for Nichols, it's also suffocating, and to the filmmaker's detriment.
While you can admire the filmmaker for his unconventional means of expressing himself, without any sense of linearity, or character development, it becomes impossible to invest in this picture.
It's very easy to be flippant with the material and lose sight of the context when a romantic narrative takes precedence - but the director never compromises on the severity of war.
By the time Lou! has finished you feel like you've downed an entire packet of popping candy and washed it down with cherryade.
Middle films in movie franchises run the risk of being devoid of closure and linearity, and it's that inconclusive nature to Robert Schwentke's Insurgent that proves to be its greatest misgiving.
Anybody who pays for a ticket to see the latest Neeson actioner will know exactly what's in store - and it's safe to say this doesn't disappoint in that regard.
There are a myriad of twists and turns and Herry never once loses you, as you remain completely captivated and intrigued as to how this tale will conclude.
This should be a profound character study, but the cliched use of flashbacks and the mawkish elements to the piece detract heavily from our own enjoyment.
While this may not be Resnais' finest work, it's a worthy final offering to mark what has been a truly illustrious career.
Focus is not a picture that reflects reality, and requires a true suspension of disbelief to fully get along with. However even then, it's still something of a struggle.
This tale is without the sufficient dramatic potential to work as a feature length film.
Mirren is as excellent as always in the lead, but the actress is let down by the filmmaker's inclination to be so cliched on occasion, undermining this narrative with frustrating conventionality.
To call this title intense would be something of an understatement, in what is a brutally disquieting watch.

Kill the Messenger is lacking in suspense, and given the nature of this film, and the way our protagonist becomes paranoid when becoming the subject of his own story - here's a film that needs a higher level of intensity.
Painfully, and desperately unfunny. Which, for a film in the comedy genre, proves to be something of a problem.
Chappie sets itself up to be a truly breathtaking study of robot and human relations, but just fails to move or compel the audience.
There are a handful of brilliant scenes (one between Whitaker and his adoptive mother played by Ellen Burstyn stands out), however they're few and far between.
Had this been any more sincere or stony-faced it simply wouldn't work, instead thriving in the frivolity of it all.
Julianne Moore's stunning turn in the deeply emotional drama Still Alice is head and shoulders above anything else achieved this year.
You know a director has done a mighty fine job when he has you caring about a piece of paper.
An uninspiring, and wholly underwhelming piece of cinema

It's of great commendation to this inspiring filmmaker that we care so much for the characters and their respective predicaments. We abide by their tales and fall for their stories, despite the fact we're continuously question whether it's all made up.
An unwanted throwback to the sort of film you'd stumble across in 1998, late on a Friday night on Channel 5.
Far too generic and cliched, and offers very little we haven't seen before.
So as we bid farewell to Phil, Stu and Alan once and for all, it's just not quite the riotous comedy you had hoped it would be.
It may be exceedingly predictable, mawkish and unbearably earnest - but what can't be disputed, is that its heart is certainly in the right place.
This film will split opinions, but one thing we can all rejoice in together, is witnessing the unhappiest blowing out of candles on a birthday cake you'll see on the big screen in a long while!
Exhilarating in parts and immensely moving in others, Rush will trigger a host of emotions from the viewer!
Hammer of the Gods avoids any real risks and lacks in distinct innovation.
A shallow and somewhat spiritless picture.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The Way, Way Back is an extremely difficult film to dislike, as one that has an amiable tone and series of endearing characters.
Ultimately, cinema is a form of entertainment and this picture does nothing but entertain.
Though an ultimately shallow piece of filmmaking - and one that is difficult to invest in emotionally - it remains a captivating and enticing piece of cinema.
Though complete with a handful of funny and touching moments, ultimately We're the Millers is too predictable a film.
Though riddled with issues - and not quite as ingenious as the first - it makes for incredibly fun viewing.
You can't deny the enjoyment to be had, but it feels all too similar to what we have seen before.
It's difficult to leave The Smurfs 2 feeling too disappointed given it's exactly as one would expect.
Despite having a story lacking in depth, The Conjuring almost feels like a master class in conventional horror movie making, as though this is the archetype of the genre.
Much of the reason why Frances Ha is a far more well-crafted and enjoyable piece of cinema than either Lola Versus or Damels in Distress.
Moments of brilliance, but on the whole a rather underwhelming cinematic debut for Alan.
It's so well shot that you can't quite believe that everything is actually in colour in real life.
An absorbing redemption tale this may be, but one that comes with a lot of baggage.

Though hilarious in parts, and heartwarming in others, The World's End has the great misfortune of simply being branded as a "fun" comedy, and one that is sadly unlikely to amount to being too much more than that.
Very little comes of The Deep, and the audience is left wanting, as we wait patiently for a revelation of some sort, or impactful finale, which never truly arrives.
Bula Quo! is absolute nonsense of the highest order.
The fact remains that the writer-director will do the best job he can, putting to use a good array of horror tools and production experience. That's always a treat to watch.

Following Renoir and Summer in February, The Artist and the Model explores the relationship between an artist and their nude model, though this is by far the most accomplished and touching of the lot.
movie_title: El artista y la modelo (The Artist and the Model) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Complete with a brooding, gentle score that compliments the picture well - Bishop is a director to keep an eye out on for sure, as we look forward to see what he does next.
If it hadn't been for the number on the back of Robinson's shirt, 42 could easily have stood for the amount of times this film makes you burst into tears.

For the second consecutive time in a row, Haroun's entry point into the film is that of an elusive, timorous character - making for a fascinating way to peer into a world we already know little about.
A sharp and witty screenplay.
Lee Hancock has provided a worthy homage to Mary Poppins, in a picture that, though somewhat fluffy, is exactly what'd you hope such a film to be.
Though the cast is very strong, the film regrettably fails to match up to its distinct potential.
A captivating, and enticing watch.
Adore is just completely absurd and melodramatic, where major things happen to our protagonists and they just brush it off.
Of Good Report can perhaps be accused of being a little contrived in its contentious approach - at times being shocking for the sake of being shocking.
Thought-provoking this may be, regrettably Abuse of Weakness is a somewhat forgettable film, deviating away from one of the most fascinating aspects of all; the movie she wants to produce.

If you're a fan of the original V/H/S production, this is bound to compel you, however if you left the last feeling somewhat disgruntled and underwhelmed, don't expect enough of an increase in quality to sway you this time around.
Paradise: Faith is not as strong as the opening picture of this portentous trio of films.
Pioneer remains a captivating thriller but is a film that seeks improvement in certain areas.
The Broken Circle Breakdown is an incredibly upsetting piece of cinema, and if you are to take one piece of advice on top of the need to see this movie - it's to pack tissues, and lots of them.
Grand Central has that rare appeal of pulling us into a world hardly seen in real life, and even less on screen.
On the surface this may appear to be a dramatic and outlandish thriller, it remains a tale you can relate to
Carlei's version has the ever unfortunate question of "what's the point?" lingering over it like a dark, menacing cloud.
Though growing considerably tedious in parts, and lagging somewhat in the middle stages, Hannah Arendt picks up once again for what is an immensely engaging climax.
Mister John carries a premise not too dissimilar to that of Only God Forgives, except where this excels, is that both Lawlor and Molloy have remembered that there is an audience watching.
Jasmine is a remarkably well constructed and tragic character and Blanchett is breathtaking in the role, and one that demands an Oscar nomination, at the very least.
Feeling somewhat similar to the likes of Frances Ha, in that it's a self-discovery tale of a woman finding herself, this does just lack that bit of class required to completely pull it off.
Though undoubtedly enjoyable in parts, Cold Comes the Night is too conventional a thriller, bringing little new to the genre.
Prince Avalanche may not pull up any trees as such, but this is a sweet film which will, at the very least, make you smile.
A quite brutal exploration of love; a notion that Dickens himself was known to portray in his work.
Now You See Me is a picture that lays all of its cards on the table, only to uncover one or two jokers in the pack.
Certainly a charming and genial tribute to Allen, it just isn't quite as accomplished or ingenious as his work.
The film remains as a very conventional, somewhat formulaic animation, which although enjoyable in parts, doesn't bring anything particularly new to the genre
The Spirit of '45 is an important piece of cinema to go and see, and one that truly represents the essence of Britain.
You're constantly asking yourself 'Will it matter if I leave half-way through this film?"?!
Vinyl is a harmless bit of good fun, and although it's easy to pick holes, it tells a good story and remains under 90 minutes long.
Although Broken City promises more than is ultimately delivered, it remains an easy to indulge in thriller.
This is 40 has plenty of funny, memorable moments to take away with you
With little going for A Good Day to Die Hard in any aspect really, it's certainly a disappointing addition to the Die Hard franchise
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Hitchcock remains an enjoyable film. A film about Hitchcock this may be, but not necessarily a film for Hitchcock fans.
On the whole, The Wee Man is a fascinating story well told - the first steps in making a decent movie.

As long as you take Gangster Squad for what it is and view it as the light-hearted (albeit very violent) drama that it's intended to be, you're bound to enjoy yourself, as despite this title's many shortcomings.

Hitting our screens on New Year's Day, let's cross our fingers and hope that Playing for Keeps isn't an indication as to how the rest of 2013 will be for cinema. Best to get it out of the way early, I suppose!

There is something definitive about Zero Dark Thirty as a piece of filmmaking, as though Bigelow is concluding the entire ordeal for us on the big screen, as a film that could well earn her yet another Oscar.
You certainly can't complain about the entertainment value of the feature. However when you strip it down and analyse is critically, there is a lot left to be desired.
Despite Love Bite's shortcomings, it is an original, undemanding story: a conventional romantic comedy about virgins it may be, but with added werewolves.
A provocative and artful thriller that is bound to intrigue and compel you.
Most definitely not the great sequel that we were all hoping for. Way too dumbed down to fit in with a rating certificate and very disappointing.
If you turned on the lights at the end of To Rome With Love, all you would see is the face of a film critic, overcome with a frustrating sense of unfulfillment.
The Dinosaur Project, is exactly what you would expect from a found footage orientated, British film about dinosaurs... but that, unfortunately, is not a positive acknowledgement.
From a critical mindset, it's a quite terrible piece of film making. However, the fact that everybody involved is aware that the film is bad works as a real saving grace.
Singer should be commended for bringing this fairytale to life triumphantly, enlarging it for the cinema screen, and adding that epic quality a film such as this requires.
Trance is halfway between being a complete mess and an absolute masterpiece.
Dark Skies is a good story, well told and one that keeps you on the edge of your seat.
All Things to All Men is relentless and entertaining in its fast paced narrative: a film that allows no respite from beginning to end.
However by whatever means you decide to watch this film, in the cinema or in the comfort of your living room, just be sure you pay this field a visit.
Hopefully there will be as much of a lasting effect on the killers as this picture has on the viewer, in a feature that isn't likely to escape you easily.
The East is a conventional thriller, which although not particularly memorable, manages to hold down your attention throughout, telling a good story and blessed with a string of good performances.
Shun Li and the Poet is a pensive and slow-burning production that will have you pondering over it for days.
movie_title: Io sono Li (Shun Li and the Poet) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A film that feels unique and innovative.
On the whole Black Rock remains a short but sweet film, yet sadly, and despite the suspenseful atmosphere and enrapturement of certain scenes, is too forgettable a feature film.
Made of Stone is breathtaking cinema, though unlike the title, the one thing that isn't made of stone is your heart, as you need to be prepared to shed a tear or two.
movie_title: The Stone Roses: Made of Stone (2013)

movie_review_blurb: World War Z is just not quite creative or original enough.
A thrilling, captivating feature.
The Wall is a riveting piece of cinema, and given it bears such a simplistic, obscure narrative, Plsler does a fine job holding down your attention throughout.
There is a lot to be admired about Wedges' Epic, as an action packed adventure movie that does little to offend and will certainly find an audience amongst the younger crowd.
Although the story holds much premise, The Eye of the Storm survives mostly off the performances of the leading cast members.
There may be shades of E.T. To this, but it just hasn't got that depth or emotional edge that makes kids films so poignantly well-rounded at times.
A silly comedy that is rife with influences from those that came before.
Metro Manila comes up trumps in every respect, but particularly within its narrative.
Funny, touching and warm-hearted, you can't ask for too much more from the first feature film by a young director, and one made on a relatively low-budget.
Comparisons to the original are inevitable yet the filmmakers deserve the right for this to be judged of its own accord and it's not a terrible movie.
Olympus Has Fallen is just riotously entertaining, and although nothing particularly new or original, it manages to keep you captivated and takes the viewer on one hell of a ride.
Although The Gatekeepers may not be quite theatrical nor dramatic enough for it to be highly recommended as a cinematic experience, this does feel like a film that really should be seen.
Although telling a decent story, on the whole The Expatriate is ultimately rather forgettable - not to mention the frustrating predictability of the narrative.
The Great Gatsby is by no means a bad production, it's just somewhat disappointing given the expectations placed upon it, and the pedigree that comes behind the vast majority of cast and crew.
One Chance is highly cliched and overly sentimental in points, where some of the dialogue is breathtakingly cringeworthy.
Filth is an ambitious project but it's one that Baird takes in his stride, as his directorial intentions are triumphant in their conviction.
This is simply charming cinema, and to counteract the film's title somewhat, it sure does leave you feeling rather warm.
In spite of the dramatic potential in the real events regrettably The Informant is a somewhat generic production, that neither does little to impress nor offend
Falling between a satirical social commentary and a full on teen comedy caper - Justin Edgar's We Are The Freaks is chaotic yet maintains a genial spirit and distinct watchability.
Suspenseful and intense in parts, darkly comic in others, there's a brilliant tone to this memorable piece, as Saulnier manages to find the perfect middle ground between humour and morbidity.
A memorable piece of cinema, that marks the continuos rise of one of Britain's most promising directors.
A moving piece of cinema.
A charming production, poignant and tender and one that is bound to move and compel you - while remaining so effortlessly subtle throughout.
While there is a sequel planned for The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel, let's just sincerely hope that this particular endeavour, though inoffensive, ends abruptly here.
The film, much like our protagonist, would benefit from letting itself be a little more uninhibited.
Though a flawed piece of cinema, The Sea marks a quite promising debut for Brown, as a film that certainly stays with you long after the credits roll.
Though the laughs are somewhat cheap, The Other Woman remains an easy to indulge in comedy, if a little conventional.
We don't leave the cinema feeling like we've just sat through a truly accomplished piece of cinema, and unfortunately, in this instance, that's what matters most.
Inherently good fun and a more than worthy trip to the cinema!
Given the strikingly colourful, vibrant aesthetic, and the South American flavour that exists, with a carnival spirit prevalent, sadly the animation is somewhat underwhelming.
This is undoubtedly a memorable, striking cinematic event, and despite whether you enjoy this picture or not, it's certainly a film for the big screen.
Though Jencks can certainly be accused of spoon-feeding his audience on occasion, he still manages to keep you compelled.
There are a handful of truly funny moments, however there isn't quite enough fluency to the dialogue.
When you reach the end of this title you feel rather exhausted, so maybe an entire season would be pushing it just that little bit too far.
Emotionally manipulative and unbearably mawkish!
If you're a fan of the first movie, which, let's face it, you most definitely are, then this will be everything you had hoped for and more.

Inane, unavailing and ultimately, rather farcical, They Came Together defies the odds and somehow manages to maintain its hilarity, despite fearing the joke will wear thin after a mere matter of moments.
A tragic, grievous subject matter handled delicately and efficiently.
There is undoubtedly a lot to be admired about this piece, and Cross has shown a lot of promise in just his directorial debut but this comedy i a film that's not particularly funny
Anderson's offering is never quite accessible or empathetic enough, and with a romance we struggle to believe in, it deems this particular project something of a failure.
Though a film that will certainly stay with you, it's difficult to know exactly who this film is aimed at, and what is to be taken away from proceedings.
movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A shrewd, well-structured narrative that has been deftly executed.
Despite the distinct talent of all of those involved - from Spacey to Mendes to Whelehan, the biggest winner in this instance is a certain William Shakespeare.
movie_title: NOW: In the Wings on a World Stage (2014)

movie_review_blurb: You don't need to like the band to appreciate this documentary either, as just seeing what the music means to others is enlightening and invigorating.
movie_title: Pulp: a Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An interesting take on becoming a folk star.
movie_title: Jolene: The Indie Folk Star Movie (Benny & Jolene) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Exceedingly irritating
Abu-Assad brings raw, human emotions into the situation, adding a poignancy to this engrossing piece of cinema.
An accomplished piece of cinema.
A little overwhelmed by its own self-indulgence and contrivance, which ultimately seeks in damaging your enjoyment of the overall piece.
If there is one thing to be said of this picture, it's to simply enjoy it for what it's worth.
This bears much promise as to what could achieved from this talented filmmaker in the future.
Blended is conventional and predictable in every way, shape and form with stereotypical aspects infuriating and needlessly employed, ensuring this film has little to no unique identity of its own.
Kids will love it!
This film is very offbeat and psychedelic in that regard, though regrettably not nearly as accomplished or engaging as Alice in Wonderland which is loosely resembles.
Concussion is wonderfully shot, a confident and accomplished debut for a filmmaker with a promising career ahead of her.
This seemingly superfluous reboot, is something of a triumph.
A terribly generic action thriller with more holes in the plot than you'll see at a golf course.
A generic, superfluous offering. There's very little in here for the adults, but kids may learn a thing or two at he very least.
Plastic is an unpredictable, albeit convoluted production that bears many twists and turns for the audience to enjoy.
The film survives mostly off the wonderful, absorbing leading performance by Binoche, in what a truly layered character to get your head around.
Edge of Tomorrow remains as an unadulterated, captivating thriller, which revels in being such unreservedly good fun.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the various positives that exist, the film does remain rather flat throughout, and you're left wanting at times, as you wait for the suspense to kick in.
Regrettably this poignant and profound story, does not feel very poignant nor profound at all.
Ride Alone is ultimately one joke stretched out into feature length form, and though tedious at times, fortunately for Story, that one joke happens to be a funny one.

If there is anything to be taken away from the film too, it's that if dancing can impress somebody like Rashida Jones, then there may well be a few new members signing up to Zumba classes across the nation.
An excruciatingly maudlin piece of cinema.

David Zellner co-wrote the screenplay with his brother Nathan, as two brothers pay homage to two other brothers who know how to make damn good movies - and yet this holds its own, in what is a more than worthy effort.
Anderson has created a whimsical, dreamlike world where anything goes, allowing him the licence to do whatever he sees fit. So by all means indulge in GBH - the sort that won't land you in jail.
Complimenting the enchanting, venturesome nature of the story, a strong balance has been achieved with this title, as a film that's touching, funny and educational.
Though it takes a short while to get used to the unique (and extremely colourful) visual aesthetic, it works a treat.
Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit is inoffensive and easy to indulge in, as a film that maintains your attention throughout - with an unrelenting and compelling final act.
Teplitzky has structured his film masterfully, as the way this tale is told, intertwining between various flashbacks, is completely seamless.

Regardless of the criticisms and shortcomings within this uninspiring biopic, Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom remains an important piece of filmmaking it's just a shame that the educational purpose of this title is not quite backed up emotionally.
Extremely subtle and touching cinema.
DiCaprio turns in one of his finest ever performances.
Great fun this may well be, but the finale signifies a distinct running out of ideas.
Jackson evidently takes great pleasure in just giving us all this wonderful sense of escapism, with some unashamed, fantastical fun to indulge in.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Whitaker's performance is one of only a few positives, as a film that ends on such an illusory, elaborate and downright absurd finale.

It's difficult to know quite what is harder to believe. The completely illusory and nonsensical nature of the absurd narrative Getaway or Ethan Hawke was able to make this in the same year he shone in Before Midnight!
Lacking in any palpable intensity and suspense, it's a challenge to fully invest in this tale, as a film that is rather cold and emotionally withdrawn.
Ultimately, Klown is just a comedy, and an excruciatingly funny one at that, even if at times it does veer into somewhat uncomfortable territory.
Another absorbing lead performance from Golshifteh Farahani in Atiq Rahimi's The Patience Stone
This film deserves to be seen in the cinema as a result, because as Eric Cantona says himself, "it's the perfect script".
Ultimately, Free Birds is a formulaic piece of cinema, and despite the relatively original idea, it doesn't go anywhere you don't expect it to, with so little risk taken along the way.
Keeps you guessing throughout, a very well written piece and yet another Oscar contender.
A film that struggles to find its own identity.
Bastards is a brooding, atmospheric piece.
There is certainly enough about this young filmmaker to suggest a bright career beckons.
The whole concept to Non-Stop is completely hackneyed and frivolous, but remains compelling given the fast paced, guessing game that ensues.
Remakes may get a lot of stick in Hollywood, as filmmakers can be accused of being somewhat lazy and uncreative in that regard.
Such mediocrity extends right up until the final moments, with a hugely anticlimactic finale.
Where this picture is truly triumphant, is within the significance of its very existence. This film simply needs to have been made, and it needs to be seen.
Need for Speed is incredibly conventional and prosaic, with so little innovation in this title, as a film we've seen countless times before.
Keeps you captivated from the opening line to the very last, this wonderfully written screenplay marks a triumphant sophomore endeavour for McDonagh.
Beauty and the Beast is one of the great, traditional love stories and this film simply feels devoid of any such romanticism, with no chemistry or spark between our protagonists of any kind.
movie_title: Beauty And The Beast (La belle et la bte) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A flawed production, certainly, but the ambition is to be admired as it's a bold piece of filmmaking, and given it feels so grand in scope.
Luna has taken the move from acting to directing with such confidence and ease.
On the plus side, for the second time this year we're witness to a lonely man travelling around on public transport with his pet cat.
There are known unknowns. There are unknown unknowns, and there are unknown knowns. Make any sense yet?!
Rather than feel like an actual film noir, instead it feels like a modern film imitating the genre, and as such struggles to compel in quite the way it should.
This takes itself far too seriously and suffers greatly as a result.
A quite remarkable piece of cinema.
There's a charm to this title, in spite of the fact it's an immensely cliched, predictable romance flick that is heavily flawed to say the least.
Such comparisons to the work of Malick, who himself was a producer on this feature, are ultimately the film's very undoing.
On the surface, In Order of Disappearance is a generic, archetypal revenge plot mission, but that doesn't prevent it being a film to indulge in and enjoy.
God Help the Girl is a quaint, pretentious film, representative of a quaint, pretentious band.
If The Monuments Men was in danger of extinction, it would take some convincing to risk your life to save it.

Though completely absurd in many ways, Bong's handling of the source material is so expertly done that we're completely immersed in this tale, allowing for ourselves to be taken wherever the South Korean director sees fit.
Aloft stirs nothing within you, not emotionally, not provocatively.

As a western it's enthralling with depth and visual splendour, resonating like sunstroke, but the film soon unfurls into a terror-fired juggernaut that macerates the senses then leaves you amazed, exhilarated and hugely entertained.
Though kids of 10 years old or so are bound to love this film (that's what matters, really), sadly the generic, unoriginal nature to this film leaves the adult audience left wanting.
Irrespective of the lack of ingenuity within this endeavour, it remains entirely watchable thanks to the affability of our eponymous protagonist.
The performance from Pugh allows for this to remain an absorbing endeavour, and she's been gifted with a multi-faceted character to get her teeth into, so nuanced and intriguing.

It's a true masterclass in storytelling, and Gunn's screenplay is tantamount to this, particularly impressive in how we understand and care for this myriad of characters - not always an easy task where ensemble features of this nature are concerned.
An overtly melodramatic, televisual endeavour that harks back to classic b-movie thrillers of the 90s.

In spite of the incessant Nazi presence, and the fact our protagonists are hiding several Jews in their home, the film somehow comes devoid of suspense, which should be the film's most prominent theme, and yet isn't nearly as prevalent enough.

A heightened take on reality, revelling in the idiosyncrasies and absurdities of every day life, and yet while doing so never detracts from the realism of the piece, as we become so caught up in this fledging relationship.

A film that depicts the golden era of Hollywood with a palpable affection, a romanticised, indelible take on Los Angeles, maintaining the glitz and glamour, yet injecting a vital gritty edge.

A fascinating study of art and expression; how it feels to be the storyteller, and how it feels to be the story - and yet regrettably such intriguing themes fall within the boundaries of a feature that plays it all too safe.

There's a relatively charming, tender tone to this piece, albeit a throwaway piece of cinema that is unlikely to linger long in the memory.

A mesmerising, horrendously uncomfortable film that lingers on every single little moment. The cutting, the bitting, the scratching or the waxing - it's a visceral piece that you won't forget in a hurry.
A nuanced, philosophical and evocative blockbuster.

A simplistic tale, told in a creative fashion - and yet despite the risks taken by the filmmaker, he never once compromises on the emotionality at hand.

A self-contained science fiction blockbuster that thrives in its simplistic premise.

A film that is too predictable in parts, never quite subverting expectations.

A striking debut that should mark the beginning on an immensely triumphant career behind the camera for Lee. Visually, narratively, emotionally - this film succeeds on every level, and does so in such an uncompromising way.
