Starter For Ten comfortably makes the grade for rib-tickling entertainment.
Thankfully, Sturgess keeps the film grounded with a rumpled, earthy charm, and Wood brings much-needed emotional depth. And yes, the songs will strike a chord as well.
War has rarely been this much fun, but director Mike Nichols is careful to offset the mischief with a poignant reminder of the days that lay ahead.
He's a terribly flawed man but instead of soapy histrionics, Condon underlines the tragedy with outrageous humour.

Despite the difficult subject matter, there is colour and energy to the storytelling that betrays a diehard optimism and is vaguely reminiscent of Pedro Almodovar's films. Aranoa keeps a loose, fluid feel to the action and ups the tempo with music.
that 'jolly hockey sticks' vibe feels outmoded with the only efforts to update the concept being shorter skirts and push-up bras.
Whilst some of the vivid detail in Khalid Hosseini's best-selling novel does get lost in translation, director Marc Forster hits all the emotional high notes.
It's impossible to say for sure, but the moral of the story could be: don't waste your time.
There's a feeling of eerie otherworldliness and the murder itself is relished in detail, however the film does lack overall impact
Approach this not as a lesson in the facts of life, just a bit of childish escapism.
The film isn't without its flaws, but in defying Hollywood convention, it manages to reach parts other comedies cannot reach.
Apparently, all the world needs a hero and there is nobody better than Brad Pitt, with all his untouchable starriness, to fill those boots.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps it shouldn't come as a surprise that a comedy about a couple of cavemen trades in primitive humour, still it's tough to imagine even the most monkey-brained of filmgoers getting a kick out of Year One.
What seems like fertile comedy territory turns out to be as barren as the North Pole.
Emile Hirsch captures all of the arrogance, integrity, naivet and charm of this complex, troubled young man.
Beyond the premise, there's nothing too surprising about this film from writer/director Robin Swicord, but it is perfectly agreeable.
A guaranteed shot of pure heart-pumping entertainment.
Essentially it's a game of verbal ping-pong and, even if cynicism wins the day too easily in the end, the interplay is lively and intriguing.
Even though the script plays fast and loose with historical facts, that indomitable bulldog spirit rings true and holds you captive for the duration.
Pleasingly anarchic.
A lazy assemblage of set-pieces that fail to add up to anything much.
Dennis Quaid and Rene Russo follow wearily in the footsteps of Henry Fonda and Lucille Ball in this asinine remake.
Despite numerous cutesy twists, it's the gradual unveiling of a warped morality that lures you into Brooks' world.
Anand Tucker has no need of bells and whistles, instead letting Colin Firth, and especially Jim Broadbent, enthral us with wonderfully vivid performances.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Those who relished Anderson's candy-coloured bittersweet style in The Life Aquatic should enjoy the trip.
A melodic wakeup call; where bluegrass meets grassroots politics.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It scores high on clichs but makes up for it with lots of fizzing energy and lively turns. Indeed it's more screwball than football.
Without a strong villain, a charismatic hero or a clear quest, it's all just a pointless frenzy, an exercise in going nowhere fast. A bit like a hamster on a wheel.
Coppola is a shadow of the director he used to be. The use of black-and-white here only shows that more starkly.
Nighy and Blunt do bring a lot of warmth and charm to their roles, but thanks to a badly judged script and lazy direction, the final showdown leaves you feeling cold.
The comedy is close to the knuckle at times, but Hill and Brand counter that with an easy chemistry, while those who normally find Brand too loud or abrasive may be surprised to see his softer side.
The action hits a dead end and the laughs dry up, but it's the budding romance between the young free spirit and the crotchety old triggerman that really kills it.
Baumbach (The Squid and the Whale) has a knack for creating clever, tension-laden dialogue that feels authentic, and there's plenty of i.
An awkward moment is comedy gold in Ben Stiller's hands and there are plenty of those in Greenberg.
Though its title must rank as one of the most off-putting in film history, Black Death isn't as bad as you might fear.
It's all talk and no action.
Like his brooding anti-hero, Johnson keeps one step ahead and, at the same time, wears his heart on his sleeve. It's tough not to fall for such charm.
British director Michael Winterbottom adapts the classic pulp fiction of American novelist Jim Thompson here, but something gets lost in translation.
It lags a touch towards the end and it's ultra quirky, but the artifice doesn't rob the finale of emotion. In fact, it delivers unexpected rewards.
Ultimately, the images stay with you for all the wrong reasons.
Herzog has unique flair, but it's out of synch with the genre. As for Cage, he is a flailing madman and the only polite thing to do is look away.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Like Willis, the formula just comes across as old and tired.
Scott delivers on spectacle, but our hero is more Mr Nice Guy than Maximus Meridius. He lacks real purpose and the film ends up being a jolly ramble through medieval times.
Soon, the action begins to feel monotonous and Marshall's answer is to pick off more victims...
Director Alejandro Amenbar makes a powerful argument for independent thought over religious faith; his portrayal of the infamous raid on the library at Alexandria is devastating and masterfully shot.
There are no original set-ups, but Carell's discomfort and Fey's futile attempts to rationalise an increasingly ridiculous situation are consistently amusing.
The real triumph of the film - apart from a beautifully shot, grand-scale recreation of Alexandria - is how it illustrates the vital importance of asking questions.
Polanski reminds us he's an old hand at building suspense and, even though the plot spirals out of control at the end, The Ghost remains deliciously unnerving.
It feels close to Gervais's heart, brimming with nostalgia for sunny days and japes with the lads.
It might feel a little bit too cute at times, but there is rarely a dull moment.
Best forgotten.
A little Gallic charm goes a long way in this engaging romantic comedy.

Even minor roles are filled by sterling talent (including Michael Caine as Cobb's mentor), which is testament to the originality and precision of Christopher Nolan. His is a mind that's definitely worth getting lost in.
Essentially, London Boulevard is a long but not very winding road.
It's far from original and, crucially, the romance between Farrell and Knightley doesn't have enough pull.
So much tension doesn't quite translate into a gutsy finale, still, this film is never less than heartfelt.
The fictionalised account of Carlos's personal life is intriguing, but the deeper root of his anger remains unclear beyond the rhetoric.
It's all so lamely poetic.
Clichs aside, this has a fresh, contemporary feel, and the cosy rapport between Barrymore and Long (on/off partners in real-life) makes it an easy ride.
Essentially, this is Currie's sob story and it can feel too self-pitying at times, though the high-wattage pairing of Stewart and Fanning keeps it together.
Fortunately, Arterton stays likeable in the role because she naturally conveys the girlish naivet of Drewe even while she's behaving like an outrageous femme fatale.
Barrymore and Long have a way of bringing out the silliness in each other and luckily, that kind of chemistry goes a long way.
The result is a dog's dinner.
Williams is able to create an unsettling atmosphere with simple sound effects, but he fails to provide a convincing context for the extreme antisocial behaviour.
Co-helmers Josh Gordon and Will Speck don't just distort the original intention of Eugenides's story, they force it kicking and screaming into a romantic comedy mould.
Most right-minded viewers will be left in a fog trying to make sense of this drivel.
If Williams has something important to say about hoodie culture, it's sadly lost in the haze of pot smoke.
It's loud and brash, but strangely endearing.
It's the kind of film that creeps up on you and sinks in long afterwards.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The body count is high, but the killing is bloodless and breezy.
Mouglalis cannot seem to find any redeeming features in Coco Chanel.
This isn't a revolution in filmmaking, but a rare kind of comedy where the actors keep it real.
Fortunately, after all the howling and growling and carnage is done, Splice does remain a very human film.
Garcia's gift for comedy is a true revelation.

Emotional intimacy is lacking, with some characters functioning merely as devices to explain an increasingly complicated scenario, but there's no doubt that Nolan knows how to craft an enthralling brainteaser.
Ultimately, this doesn't have the emotional resonance of the similarly-themed caper In Bruges, but it does keep you smiling.
A little Irish charm goes a long way in this Dublin-set crime caper.
The film remains outrageously funny without resorting to cheap gags.
There's a spellbinding, painterly quality to the way Campion depicts the changing seasons (between 1819 and 1820) and it sets a mood that complements the poet's vivid and sensuous style.
Without a steady build of tension, 90 minutes ends up feeling like two hours. More like Dead Man Plodding.
What makes An Education so memorable is that it's a study of a teenage girl that looks beyond face value.
Few filmmakers have managed to capture all the cheekiness and whimsy of Roald Dahl's books, but indie helmer Wes Anderson brushes very close to a flawless adaptation of Fantastic Mr Fox.
Entertainment on a par with sitting through your neighbours' holiday slideshow.
A hit and miss comedy.
As the end of the road finally draws near, you'll need to pull over and throw up.
A wryly amusing, imaginative tale.
Letekidan Micael sets the screen alight in this alarming and memorable story of a child soldier.
It's a boldly small approach to a big subject and, except for Bettany's performance, it feels miscalculated.

The Soloist isn't the cringe-worthy Rain Man rip-off it might have been, but that's the only surprise this film has to offer. If it were a piece of music, it would be the kind you hear in a lift when you're stuck between floors...
Think of it like a good souffl: deliciously sweet and airy without the cloying aftertaste. You'll want more.
An endorphin rush of a movie, which even in its saddest moments is uplifting funny.
The visceral impact is intense.
Aside from being long-winded, the action is contrived; veering from slapstick to saccharine. That's a pity for Sandler because he shines for the most part.
Almodvar's natural affinity with women (particularly women who are forced to act tough) enables an easy balance of noirish grit and that high melodrama which has become his trademark.
Basterds is not as the closing dialogue suggests, a masterpiece, but even an off-day Tarantino can still impose shock and awe.
As powerful as a time-machine made Blue Peter-style out of cardboard and empty bottles.
Definitely not just for the fashion slaves; this is an inspiring portrait of a woman who cut her own cloth to fit.
Scott does like his bells and whistles, substituting those for real atmosphere and sense of place. Fortunately that's not enough to completely wreck a serviceable thriller.
Like a valley of sedimentary rock, the film is comprised of layer upon crumbling layer of dumbness.
The film is just so darned entertaining.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This Hollywood adaptation is as glossy as Christmas wrapping paper and just as disposable.
An extraordinary life winds up feeling like a series of random blips on the radar screen.
Poliakoff cleverly translates the mood of fear and uncertainty in Britain into a dark psychological maze that leads Anne to the edge of insanity.
Carrey is definitely the star of the film, but McGregor remains the emotional anchor.
Kids will drool at Burton's spectacle - grown-ups too - but they might also find this isn't the nostalgia trip they hoped for. Where's the bottle marked 'Feel Me'?
otal fluff and nonsense - though director Kolton Lee does demonstrate visual flair on a low budget - this is also disingenuous and patronising.
Bridges is totally at ease singing the blues, so much so that it's easy to forget those creaks in the script, as he delivers an iconic performance that's guaranteed to pluck the heartstrings.
The finale - though tense - lacks that visceral gut punch. Ultimately, Jackson spends too long in the clouds and loses touch with the real drama on ground level.
Marshall directs like a giddy Cupid, spreading the joy thinly among the multitudes. Still, if we learn anything from this Valentine's movie, it's that even a bit of what you fancy does you good.
While the special effects and occasional chase scenes might be enough to pacify the younger crowd, grown-ups will find it curiously bloodless.

It's a bold comeback by Hollywood's prodigal son, but he doesn't beg for sympathy either. If only such guts could be found in the script - instead of splattered all over the floor at the last minute - this might have been a classic.
Despite an intriguing premise, it doesn't really go anywhere.
The plot does feel sketchy and drawn-out at times, but overall, this film packs a punch.
This is a flawed film, but the quirks and foibles are what keep it interesting.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Hillcoat's raw and sparing approach is sympathetic to the novel. Even after it's over, it continues to burn.
This could have been Dances With Wolves on acid, but instead it's like a rave with hippies (on acid). Trippy, but not as deep as it thinks it is.
[Jonze's] take on Maurice Sendak's much-loved children's book does offer plenty of wildness and wackiness, although it's also unusually sombre.
The fact that she looks like Carrie will only serve as a reminder that they just don't make 'em like they used to. This is what you call 'plumbing the depths...'
It's a shame that Grey isn't as rehearsed in baring her soul instead of her body, still The Girlfriend Experience boasts enough intrigue to keep you hooked.
The biggest revelation of the film is that it packs real, raw emotion in spite of so much artifice.
If the first instalment of The Twilight Saga was a celebration of teenage sulkiness, then this sequel positively drowns in it.
An amusing if rather too glib thriller.
It's challenging, only if you want it to be. The secret to enjoying it, like life, is not to obsess over the bits that don't appear to make sense.
Most of the movie is concerned with the glum, lonely Bella, who just doesn't know what to do with herself - and it looks as though the film-makers were similarly stumped.
Damon conveys the vulnerability of his character, but the script fails to explore why Whitacre makes the choices he does. He's simply buffoonish.

The views of Victorian London are just as seductive as Downey Jr, who exudes an aura of troubled genius, though that's all the information you're likely to retain, as there's rarely a moment to think between all the fights and explosions.
Opening Night is a truly grand unveiling of our innermost fears.
Although it sounds like the Aboriginal answer to a Harrison Ford kidnap thriller, this is actually a richly textured parable.
As ever the chemistry between the lads -- especially Clooney and Pitt -- keeps the rhythm snappy, and this time, the emphasis on friendship and loyalty makes them easy to root for.
This stunning lack of inspiration is reflected in a script that continually hints at how teenagers have become disenchanted with politics without ever following it up.
Only The Beatles' Yellow Submarine equals The Life Aquatic With Steve Zissou for brilliant, psychedelic surrealism.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Shall We Dance? stumbles into a tight corner between comedy and romance, failing to satisfy on either count.
Even when it misses the mark, SpongeBob drips with originality.
Richet introduces new twists and simmering character drama while avoiding pretensions to conserve the ferocity of the 1976 original.
Although not as disarmingly funny the second time around, inspired casting means that, unlike most in-laws, the Fockers don't outstay their welcome.

Despite the combined talents of Emmy Rossum and Gerard Butler, its tragic love story between an opera-singing novice and her disfigured mentor is horrifically bloated with theatrical gestures and falsetto dialogue.
As the titular conqueror, Colin Farrell shows the limit of his screen presence as he falters in such big boots and winds up face first in the sand.
It's utterly devoid of suspense.
movie_title: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This movie couldn't be more stale if it'd been dug up by archaeologists.
A witty, wacky, and wonderful trip through the minefield of being twenty-something.
Rather than wallow in cynicism, Fellini's genius is characterised by a zest for life -- albeit a tragically insatiable one -- as he sprinkles dreamlike snapshots like glitter in the darkness.
Besides its dead-eyed cast, this 'animated' escapade is thrown off the tracks by pointless detours seemingly intended just to stretch the journey time.
Like an adrenaline rush, Riding Giants is fun for a while but it ends on a comedown.
All that's vaguely funny or Christmassy about this are the sweaty beads of desperation which string together like fairy-lights across Affleck's forehead as he hammers out one lame gag after another.
Never binds into a satisfying whole.
Spacey weaves real-life drama with musical set-pieces to create a vibrant and whimsical portrait.
The combo of exotic lady and exotic location fails to distract from varying and unsuccessful attempts to blend romance and comedy with half-hearted heist intrigue.
Flies high above the crowd for its worldly wit and compassion for humankind.
At best this is a witty and insightful portrait of a woman searching for her true identity; however it's also aloof and inconsequential.
Wholly lacking in conviction.
A warm and witty comedy brimming with sharp insights.
Essentially, the anchor doesn't go deep enough and Shark Tale is left to flounder.
All the performances are strong, with Portman especially fearless and Owen simply fearsome as a man driven by his base instincts.
Brooks' championing of good old-fashioned family values feels hopelessly nave and frankly unconvincing.
It's like Spinal Tap, only shorter.
It's the groundbreaking combination of toe-tapping tunes and wailing pathos, which makes this a truly arresting musical.
A pleasant surprise out of leftfield.
You will leave the cinema utterly disenchanted.
Outrageous set-ups and saucy dialogue keep the party going and, while it staggers erratically to its conclusion, Wedding Crashers always has its heart in the right place.
It's not pitch perfect but the leads make a winning team.
An intoxicating endorphin rush.

Although not as scathingly funny as the Ryan-Crystal classic, director Nigel Cole offers an engaging romance infused with the warmth and optimism of his previous films Calendar Girls and Saving Grace.
Initially writer/director Jill Sprecher seems to revel in fashionable cynicism, but her ability to look at the lighter side and her discreet faith in human nature eventually win out.
Echoing the black wit of the Jack Nicholson/Kathleen Turner classic Prizzi's Honor (1985) but with a screwball pace and doses of hi-tech action, it's not to be missed.
[A] fiercely original crime anthology that hits right between the eyes with a striking blend of old-school noir and newfangled comicbook visuals.
Like the eponymous cat, it'll leave you feeling warm and fuzzy.
Fiendishly good fun.
Ultimately it doesn't amount to much, but like Starks' drug-induced trip, The Jacket is about the journey not the destination.
As forgettable as a Hollywood couple's marriage vows.
The laughs are few and far between.
Latifah carries the weight of this film and does an impressive job given a script that's crying out for a total restyle.
Bullock struts her stuff well, but this comedy lacks freshness and sags in all the wrong places.
It's impossible to empathise because the circumstances are so ridiculously contrived.
Dazzling set-pieces keep things ticking over.
Simply put: a violation.
Be afraid: it's Home Alone meets The Exorcist.
The story never comes into its own, only skimming the surface of Barrie's obsession and failing to grasp the psychological ties underlying his most intimate relationships.
Wayans takes one (unfunny) joke and runs with it far beyond the realms of plausibility to a point where even Michael Jackson would draw the line.
What Chadha loses in the sly subtext that made Austen's novel so compelling, she makes up for with wit and mischief.
While it is bold, ambitious and often striking, In The Cut isn't as incisive as it pretends to be.
What should lift your spirit only threatens to eject your lunch.
One of the most inspired, scathing, and downright side-splitting comedies to come out of Hollywood this year.
Guaranteed to blow you away.
Watching it is rather like finding yourself impaled on a steel rod. It is sharp, cold, and thoroughly riveting.
It's the casting that provides balance, and low-key laughs.
Peter Collinson's The Italian Job (1969) is not a great film -- it's an average film with a great finale. Oh, and another thing: F Gary Gray's remake blows the bloody doors off it.
A keenly observed, captivating, and innately funny portrait of teenagers coming to terms with their sexuality.
There's something irresistible about this teenybopping hoofer.
Ultimately descends into the kind of tabloid sensationalism surely not befitting the no-nonsense journalist.
Every bit as bold and uplifting as its title suggests.
While Confidence is packed with all the ballsy bombast of Glengarry, it lacks the heart-stopping tension.
The pairing of Nicholson and Sandler is golden.
In a starry line-up it's Jude Law who commands most presence, playing the charmer so well that his absence in the latter half leaves a gaping void.
An enjoyable if sudsy growing pains yarn.
The friction between [Martin's] button-down lawyer, Peter Sanderson, and ghetto-fabulous fugitive Charlene Morton (Queen Latifah) produces dazzling comic sparks in an otherwise stale set-up.
Murphy has no comic timing and Kutcher overcompensates.
Miller's film is bold and hearty, but it's also a ham-fisted wallop to the senses.
An honestly intimate and genuinely funny account of bereavement.
While Frida is no masterpiece, it's nevertheless worth the price of admission to see Hayek master her craft.
The bizarre casting sets the tone for a romantic comedy which mistakes asinine for amusing.
Even with its faults, Gordon's The Singing Detective will haunt the darkest corners of your mind long after the curtain falls.
It makes for a tabloid account, albeit a deliciously droll sidebar to The Selling Of A Serial Killer.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Hardwicke shows great instincts, using a frenetic documentary style to hammer home the brutal realities of modern teenage life, but rooting it in an unusually sensitive portrait of mother and daughter.

It's a conventional but pleasantly cosy remake of the 1976 Jodie Foster body-swap comedy. And in the oldest tradition of Disney moviemaking, you can be sure of a few life lessons thrown in between the laughs.
Fascinating from start to finish.
The differing styles of the two comedians never meld, but the script is so flabby even an industrial crane couldn't lift it.
Famed for his way with words, it's as if Mamet has tried to outdo himself here, but without the trademark humour that might've lifted this otherwise constipated Tom Clancy knock-off.
Kentis ends up treading water until, finally, the whole film gets sucked under.
Raimi weaves a wonderfully seductive web of arachnid action, human drama, and wink-nudge comedy.
A cinematic oasis, both refreshing and thoroughly life-affirming.
movie_title: The Story of the Weeping Camel (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Director Frank Coraci plays fast and loose with Jules Verne's classic tome Around The World In 80 Days, but his adaptation never runs out of gas.
Consistently throughout the film, Stickler skates right over the crux of the matter.
movie_title: Stoked: The Rise and Fall of Gator (2003)

movie_review_blurb: This isn't funny enough or dramatic enough.
Although raising intriguing questions about the moral obligation dramatists have to throw a spotlight on taboo subjects, The Reckoning offers simplistic solutions.
It sounds like a touchy-feely Gap commercial, but this fantastical premise jars with a refreshingly realistic look at girls making the tricky transition to womanhood.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Although the premise is rather obvious, and at times a little too full of its own whimsy, the portrayal of the women is very incisive.
This movie lacks any complexity. Dutton opts instead to embellish the story with boxing clichs.
Meanders aimlessly until eventually falling flat on its face.
A lovingly observed elegy to lost innocence, conveying the emotional complexity of bereavement with the naivet of a child's perceptions.
movie_title: Dyskoloi apohairetismoi: O babas mou (Hard Goodbyes: My Father) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: This is, to cut to the chase, a masterpiece.
Barrymore wanders through scenes as if she has trouble remembering what day it is.
This is a gem of a movie that, like its protagonist, boasts a fiercely independent spirit full of discreet optimism and deadpan humour.
It's a consistently amusing tale thanks largely to the eminently watchable cast.
It's irreverent without crossing the line, and hits a tender note without lapsing into maudlin sentiment.
With all the legs flailing, earnest speechifying, hot-headed outbursts, and mild abuse of crockery, Robert Benton's adaptation feels more like a fat Greek wedding than an Ancient Greek tragedy.
There's not a word or a wistful glance out of place in Sofia Coppola's offbeat comedy drama.
A hugely entertaining film, sprinkled with moments of brilliance.
Everything bad about teen chick flicks is encapsulated in The Perfect Man.
Festival will surely tickle your funny bone.
It could be part-autobiographical for director John Schultz who blunders through a tediously half-baked plot and fails to make it pay off.
Towards the end, the spectacle of Milly faking an orgasm for her mother's edification is, frankly, enough to kill anyone's hopes of romance.
Grant and Barrymore just don't have the depth or chemistry to make you care. In short: flat like Milli Vanilli.
Shrewdly adapted from Zo Heller's best-selling novel, Notes On A Scandal grabs your attention with a gentle touch and refuses to let go.

The songs themselves aren't memorable so it helps greatly that they're delivered with gusto. Condon tries to pack too much in, however, and energy flags slightly towards the end. Ultimately it's Hudson's passion that keeps the dream alive.
Presents a blinkered look at the man and what he meant to Americans in the turbulent 60s, but nobody can accuse Estevez of lacking sincerity.
Who could be better suited than Peter O'Toole to the role of an actor growing old disgracefully?
Babel can be unnecessarily convoluted, ultimately though it's the stark simplicity of the dilemmas faced by each character that hits home, wherever that may be.

[Director Joe] Carnahan aims for a Tarantino-style black comedy but wildly misses the mark. Instead of crafting characters to laugh with (or at, even) he indulges a sniggering schoolboy obsession with casual mutilation and silly wigs.
It's packed with left-field twists and turns and culminates in a genuinely nail-biting match where old rivalries come to a head. In the end, it's all you can do not to stand up and cheer.
If anything this film proves that song can have more impact than a little toe tapping and tub-thumping.
This tale of dragons and derring-do risks sending kids and grownups alike drifting away to the Land Of Nod.
This romantic comedy ends up feeling soggy, syrupy and so bloating it'll put you to sleep before the pudding's done.
The film is a guaranteed tearjerker, but more than that, an uplifting tribute to a single woman's quest for independence that would surely make Bridget Jones blush.
Tugs at the heartstrings, chills to the bone.
Showcasing a glittering array of comedy talent from Ben Stiller to Ricky Gervais, Night At The Museum is a rare family treat.
Everything comes to a head in a touchy-feely climax (if you catch our drift) where, ironically, it isn't the strong sex but all the singing and handholding that's the real turn-off.
Instead of finishing with a bang it peters out, but this existential yarn is still fresh and funny enough to justify taking two hours out of your life.
Generally the story swings wildly from preachy to just plain silly. It is truly a story of missed opportunities.
It doesn't sound like a barrel of laughs, but [director Michael] Cuesta finds wry humour in tragic situations while at the same time thickening the air with quiet foreboding.
It's a beautifully insightful story co-written by Field and Tom Perrotta (based on his novel) that is sometimes unsettling but always engrossing, and ultimately heart-warming.
It's a typical politician's tale -- all talk and no action.
Ironically, in an attempt to give Africans a voice, Sissako drowns them out.
Orchestra seats are supposed to bring us closer the action, but in the end, this film is definitely more middle row.
Haylie and sister Hilary Duff just don't have the comedy stylings to sell this half-baked story of heiress sisters battling to save their dad's cosmetics empire from ruin.
Thanks to the combined charm of the leads, this remains a most agreeable cinematic portrait.
Posin aims for are out of his reach and he's left to scrabble desperately for a story to plug in the gaps.
In the end, it fails to tug the heartstrings.
[Director] Lawrence certainly knows how to bait his audience with intriguing characters.
This is an unusually bold film, but it's also a morality tale that's riddled with hypocrisy and is frankly offensive. Not a blues movie as much as a blue movie.
If great minds think alike, they'll be giving this one a miss.
Despite a few knots in the story, that trademark combo of warmth, wit and charm keeps you hanging.
Rather like a fungus-based meat substitute, this film feels as though it's good for you, but actually there are few lasting benefits.
Overall this is a satisfyingly slow-burning romance, beautifully scored and acted.
Exploitative and depressing.
A low-key yet powerful and uplifting story of love renewed amid the ravages of old age.
Debut director Anne Fletcher fails to put a new spin on umpteen romantic hoofers.
It's a portrait of political activism that makes John and Yoko's bed-in look lively.
Truly evocative.
... you just cannot help but watch...
It is repetitive at times, occasionally lagging, but the performances by Oldman and especially Molina simply demand your attention.

Juliette Lewis helps break the monotony with a sparkling turn as a ditsy skeleton in the dead fianc's closet and Kevin Smith spouts a few good zingers as the slacker housemate. Sadly it's not enough to catch and keep hold of your interest.
The settings are mundane, but the exchanges are emotionally raw and so neatly convey both the drama and the grinding daily routine of having to cope with tragedy.
Sather has a couple of amusing moments as the bumbling ladies' man (furiously scribbling notes on how to exude a relaxed air), but overall what we're left with is a very limp portrait of manhood.
Certainly the film isn't without its flaws. Then again, perfection is in the eye of beholder.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: In all it's an unconvincing portrait, and as the Dylan clone says, "Empty, like one of those cans of soup..."
The Yard is a minefield of clichs - step at your peril.
This mightn't be as fun as a Big Fat Greek Wedding, but there's at least as many broken plates afterwards...
It takes a while to settle into the rhythm (feeling episodic at first), but Half Nelson soon takes hold with a vice-like grip.
An engaging and moving tale.
This mightn't be food for the soul, but it is a pleasurable sugar rush.
The real joy is in a smoulderingly sinister turn by Meryl Streep as Andy's egomaniacal boss.
It sounds like a vehicle with plenty of comedy mileage, but Failure To Launch quickly runs out of steam.
At best it's a bumpy ride through predictable territory.
The story isn't inherently funny, relevant, or convincing.
For anyone over 12 years old, this is a date to be missed.

Once more, Wong raises questions of fate and predestination and, while throwing in a tasteless reference to 9/11, fails to address them. It's an orgy of cheerful carnage with no context or purpose and, worst of all, no suspense.
For patient viewers, it does offer a carefully considered and ultimately inspiring examination of how the need for order and logic is less important than a willingness to embrace chaos.
If fun means money, this is near bankrupt.
Like Cillian Murphy in high heels, Breakfast On Pluto totters along with unnerving hesitancy.
Unlike the geisha, this adaptation does wear its heart on its sleeve, but a fine cast, including the regal Michelle Yeoh, create a picture of composure.
Brokeback Mountain is a truly epic romance story from a director at the peak of his powers.
... it is refreshing to see a love story played out with sincerity.
Despite its flaws, The Family Stone sparkles bright with originality.
Lewis' fantasy is beautifully realised in a vast array of colourful characters and majestic scenery.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
A simple story, lovingly polished.
Like Justin, Mills struggles to make his point, but even so, this is a tender portrait of teenhood.
It's the too-cute contrivances on which the story is built that mean it's always teetering on the verge of collapse.
Makes an agreeably refined accompaniment to a bucket of popcorn.
[Scott] directs this 'sort of true' crime story about English schoolgirl-turned-bounty hunter Domino Harvey like a rabid dog with a rag doll in its gnashers.
Emma Thompson is a treat as the eponymous childminder.
If you have a pulse, you'll love it.
As styles diverge, unease creeps in and overshadows the actors.
A scattering of dance sequences that fuse hip-hop and classical beats provide a few shots of energy, but Take The Lead otherwise plods through the motions.
Subtlety and sincerity go out the window in favour of crass stereotypes and easy jibes ...
Unlike Franco's mop, no amount of teasing can keep this romance from falling flat.
A deeply moving, life-affirming tale -- the many scathing one-liners are just icing on the cake.
It only works in fits and starts and the grand climax is too Rocky Horror to be true, yet the heady redolence of a bygone era still proves seductive.
The story is as compelling as watching the ink dry on a superfluous UN treaty.
David Duchonvy and Julianne Moore make an engaging double-act and an undercurrent of droll humour keeps things zipping along quite amiably for the most part.
The tabloid appeal is obvious, but Morgan's script is tomorrow's chip paper.
It's not seamless, but Wilson fans can safely roll out the welcome mat.
John Tucker will surely die and be quickly forgotten.
All roads lead to dead ends, in dramatic and investigative terms.
There are some laughs to be had, albeit not always in the right places. A resounding plop.
Despite tackling death and dysfunction, indie comedy drama Little Miss Sunshine radiates warmth and charm.
The real power is in the simple contrast of despair and hope, the latter embodied in a pregnant woman who seeks protection from a typically world-weary Clive Owen.
Harron is not judgemental in her approach, which allows Bettie's sweet nature to shine through. However, there's a nagging dissatisfaction that comes from being too detached from her subject.
It's a tidy showcase for Cate Blanchett as a recovering drug addict struggling to throw off the shackles of her past, but Sam Neill and Hugo Weaving also shine ...
Like the story of many broken down relationships: despite the initial attraction, you're left feeling cheated.
Make your own luck and skip this twaddle.
A film that will have you both squirming in your seat and teetering on the edge of it.
There's a scattering of funny moments in Confetti, but they're dispersed over a wide area where not much really happens.
Like the desert beyond, the film is arid and airless.
For supervising grownups, its giddy leanings will induce seasickness.
It's a shame the film ends so unconvincingly, but Friends With Money is still rich in insights.
Even with its shortcomings, Brick provides solid thrills for film noir fans.
The dusty backdrop evokes a palpable sense of transience and the lingering past, but there's ultimately very little beneath the gesturing.
With such an amiable cast and lots of crisp dialogue, you can forgive the chinks in the armour.
The Voyage of the Dawn Treader should have been a great, seafaring adventure and instead it's a wishy-washy affair where all-aboard seem rather wet, for all the wrong reasons.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: You may even feel guilty for laughing except that Blanchett knows where to draw the line and she treads it gracefully - despite all those martinis.
Like Black, the story sags in the middle. Still, he's an irresistible force of nature.
If the comedy isn't as dark as the first film aspired to be, it's at least more even in tone, and the would-be kidnappers are good value.

When the trio have a bit of good writing to work with, the scenes catch fire and when they're dealt damp squibs, they go into overdrive with improvised dialogue and just about manage to get over the bumps.
Skeletons tumble out of the closet in rather a clumsy fashion, so it's just as well that Horovitz has managed to attract a refined cast who are able to put some meat on those old bones.
The storytelling is warped by the same freakishness and hysteria that afflicts its characters. For all its surface polish, The Homesman is tainted at heart.
Tom Hardy is ideal casting in what is, essentially, a character study of a loner with an uncommonly strong moral code, albeit warped by his environment.
There is no sentimentality in Andy Goddard's direction and in fact, Thomas's utter disregard for how his actions impact on Brinnin (and his wife, back home in Wales) makes him tough to like.
The signposts to a happy ending become easier to spot as the film goes on, still the ride is lively, funny and subtly poignant.
A few sections feel more loosely scripted to make the most of Wiig and Hader's talent for improvisation, but their rapport goes deeper.
Imagine a Tim Burton animation splashed with bold, bright colour and you'll have some idea of what to expect from Book of Life.
Imagine a film portrait of Jimi Hendrix without the drugs that killed him at 27 and the rock that would make him immortal.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Gutierrez not only breaks taboos around death, he turns the pieces into confetti and throws a great big fun fiesta.
What separates this from a pack of high school dramas is the isolation everyone feels, as well as the lack of sensationalism when it comes to portraying their acts of rebellion.
A seriously crushing, irresistible force of a movie.
This is a fascinating, lusciously detailed portrait of an artist, but it could have used a little less colour and a bit more subtle shading.
Bier is digging hard for something deep and yet, at the point when you should be reaching for the hankie, it's only because of so much sweaty desperation.
Reitman and co-writer Erin Cressida Wilson (adapting Chad Kultgen's novel) fumble through the plot like groping teenagers.
The Hunger Games meets Lord of the Flies in this fast-paced and enjoyably moody teen thriller adapted from the bestselling novel by James Dashner.
The tonal shifts can be a touch jarring, but there is a thin line between comedy and tragedy that is all the more poignant seen through innocent eyes.
movie_title: What We Did on Our Holiday (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Better to think of it as a Denzel Washington movie, a so-so effort that would have been a lot slicker if his old cohort Tony Scott had been at the helm.
The banter between leads Colin Firth and Emma Stone doesn't have the crackle to lift its flat story about a conjurer and a self-proclaimed psychic.
Lacking any kind of sparkle, Magic in the Moonlight is destined to become a footnote in the career of writer/director Woody Allen.
The Pope won't be convinced - but anyone who loves Bill Murray will be delighted to see him sanctified.
While there are shades of Neeson's avenging angel in the Taken franchise, this is a different, more challenging proposition for the actor.
Here's a submarine thriller that delivers on tension but doesn't get too deep.
A Christmas tale that has a slightly rougher edge than usual, yet still brims with good will to all men - even hardened criminals.
Like many a grifter, this crime caper is all style and no substance.
This is pure wish fulfilment for retirees, an over-the-rainbow, Monsoon Wedding fantasy to break the monotony of trips to the Co-op, endless cups of tea and Countdown in the afternoon.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Few films are more annoying than a con caper that has nothing up its sleeve except cool, designer style and Focus falls squarely into that category.
Essentially a saccharine confection of clichs, full of bits that are hard to swallow.
The overall effect is magical. If the technology allowed, we would shout it from the rooftops: you must see this film!
Aniston plays her part with no frills, but she can't help but be dragged down by the surrounding artifice. For one thing, no-one in the real world could possibly have so many grey cardigans.
If you think a film about computer hackers furiously tapping their keyboards sounds a bit dull, Blackhat proves you right.
[David Oyelowo] gives a huge, heartfelt performance (iniquitously ignored by the Academy) and he seems mindful, too, that the story is bigger than one man.
Johnny Depp is in danger of being upstaged by his own moustache in this knockabout crime caper.

Wahlberg can deliver a soliloquy on life as a game of chance with rat-a-tat rhythm, but he walks and talks like he's too cool for school, never properly conveying the deep well of angst that he keeps banging on about.
Mortdecai, the film, is neither satire nor spoof, instead getting caught uncomfortably in a place where the butt of the joke is difficult to pinpoint.
Valle avoids clumsiness in exploring that internal landscape and Witherspoon, too, gives a delicate, sensitive and gutsy performance...
More than an action film, this is a melodrama that demonstrates rather than examines the psychological burden of having to decide who lives and who dies.
To avert your eyes is impossible. This is a film that creeps up on you, pins you down and will not let go.
Angelina Jolie takes a conventional but confident approach to directing the amazing life story of Louis Zamperini.
In a world still being torn apart by religious conflict, the film does have a resonance beyond the grand visual sweep that Scott can always be relied upon to deliver.
Wallis is the only one among the cast to bring some real energy to the screen...

Jim Carrey and Jeff Daniels were loveable idiots when they first played Lloyd and Harry in 1994, but now they're older, none the wiser and needlessly abrasive, which takes the fun out of their stupid antics.

It isn't just that the joke has gotten old - and the actors look tired - it's that the Farrelly brothers push too hard for jaw-dropping moments, robbing the characters of the innocence and spirit of camaraderie that once balanced the stupidness.
This isn't a happily ever after kind of fairytale, but it seems that Marshall and Disney haven't really come to an agreement on what kind of story it should be and crucially, who it's aimed at.

Jackson is never more at home in Middle-earth than when he's pitting these mythical creatures against each other in physical conflict and the five-way battle when it erupts is, indeed, a roaring, seismic wave of extravagant sword-n-sandals action.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Smith carefully balances light and shade in all aspects of the film.
Up-and-comer Joey King is the only bright spot as Aidan's teenage daughter Grace who is fanatically committed to her Orthodox faith, arguably in the absence of strong parental guidance.
What might have been a smart, insightful thriller is instead a creepy bedtime story.
Sweaty, naked panic is a poor substitute for genuinely raw humour, so the movie comes across like The Benny Hill Show, Uncut.
It looks and feels very familiar, but being such a lean, mean tightly-woven thriller also makes it a refreshing break from the contemporary norm.
Despite his exaggerated, expressionless appearance, Fassbender subtly conveys the sadder elements of this story about a man whose head begins to weigh heavily on his shoulders.
The friction between Rogen and Efron is bitterly amusing, especially because Efron remains a likeable guy, and Byrne is amusingly crazy, too.
Apart from the half-baked script, Harington and Browning don't generate enough fire between them and after the curtain falls, the only question that stirs in your gut is: Pepperoni, or plain...?
Overall, the film is a bit hit and miss and Stoller tends to cross the line, but the neighbours don't outstay their welcome.
Cassavetes is certainly guilty of dragging out the action and overcooking the finale, but this all makes for good naughty fun, nonetheless.
There are enough laugh-out-loud moments and an infectious sense of naughty fun to keep you watching to the bitter, bitter end.
If the plot is a bit clumsy, that's more than made up for with sheer exuberance and plenty of cheeky banter.
This is a well-judged, well-acted, absorbing drama and an exciting break from the norm because - in the figurative sense - there are no signposts.
There's a lot of emotional to-and-froing between the characters that slows the pace, although the ongoing tussle with Electro supplies a much needed jolt whenever required.
You just have to go with it. This is pure unadulterated wish-fulfilment for the over-50s with a sunset ending that could have been sponsored by Saga Holidays.
If traditional westerns witnessed the bloody transition from anarchy to civilisation, Calvary sees that process reversed - punctuated by the burning of the chapel.
Farhadi weaves a very sticky web with more than a few ragged edges, but even if the characters (and more precisely, their actions) aren't easy to relate to, they are compelling.
Perhaps we're supposed to be laughing? Given the constantly wavering tone, it seems writer/director Jill Soloway doesn't really know what she wants.

Nostalgia is an integral part of the formula here, with familiar tracks (and voices) chiming to reams of archive material that are cut together with infectious rhythm and zip by director Morgan Neville.
Despite getting a critical hammering in the States, it turns out that romantic drama Labor Day isn't all that bad.
As soon as O'Connell comes striding through the prison door, his aura is electric.
... a typically vivid portrait of humanity and chaos which deserves your patience despite an uneven pace.
Wes Anderson delivers a luxury film experience in the shape of The Grand Budapest Hotel, a feast for the eyes with a ritzy, glitzy cast and touches of comedy gold courtesy of Ralph Fiennes.
What disappoints is his reluctance to engage with the matter of why many were happily seduced by the fascist propaganda - a question that is still relevant today.
[Goldsman] wants us to believe in miracles, but a bit of common sense would have helped.
A little bit of fun, but the memory fades.
Loach and Laverty are obliged to emphasise the violence to stoke the fire in Jimmy's belly, because all they have to define their hero are the forces that oppose him.
The idea of history repeating itself is already writ large, here, but what isn't so familiar is the casting of Tom Cruise as a coward.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There are countless missed opportunities in Grace of Monaco, a sponsorship deal with Ferrero Rocher being chief among them.
Even though the whole thing lacks depth, it is made with passion.
A comedy drama that offers a portrait of the Emerald Isle that is contrived in its quaintness.
Strip away the supernatural framework and this is just another teen romance with an add-on message about chasing dreams - not just boys - to keep it politically correct.
Gleeson is a strong anchor and brings some complexity to his part; it's just that he isn't served well by a script that too often mistakes bluntness for irony.
The plot may be easy to fathom, but the undercurrents are astutely played by the actors as they're forced to confront some uncomfortable truths and, somehow, move on.

Besson is audacious, bending time and space at [Lucy's] will with comic effect - in the sense that it's funny and reminiscent of a kitsch cartoon strip - only pausing briefly every now and then for a bit of philosophical musing.

This is satire with only a touch of lightness and that's mainly in the dazzling, retro animation which turns Tom Cruise (another of Green's 'properties') into little more than a row of big pearly white teeth.
It's all too obvious and a bit glib.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This space caper has its head in the clouds and its tongue, firmly in cheek.
The man, whose chest is tattooed with the name Dayani Cristal, may be a victim of circumstance, but he is also treated by the filmmakers as a hero on a quest.
Had Cuesta dug a bit deeper around these characters, he might have struck gold. As it is, Kill the Messenger is worth writing home about.

Green doesn't take the obvious route, looping in and out of a series of incidents instead of chaining them too tightly in cause and effect, creating real intrigue around Joe and his impulse to destroy.
Despite McCarthy's energy in front of the camera, Tammy too often wanders off track.
The Anomaly has all the ingredients of a winning formula, in the wrong measures.
The food, the company and the sparkling conversation give the film an intoxicating feel-good buzz and if it's all a bit indulgent, Favreau makes no apologies. He revels in it.
Eastwood's rough-and-ready style aptly reflects his young subjects, who are brimming with roguish charm.

Kurt Russell and Matt Dillon are short-changed by a script with a clever denouement that comes at the expense of the rest of the action, which is so self-consciously cool and vacuous, it's practically freeze-dried.
Based on the bestselling book by Reif Larsen, this whimsical adventure is a feast for the eyes but only a light snack for the soul.
movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: An awe-inspiring epic of man versus nature (inspired by true events during WWII) as a group of escaped prisoners run 40,000 miles over hostile terrain.
It plays like The Polar Express in summertime, except that Jeunet at least has a better feel for the storybook aesthetic.
movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Explosive stunts aside, it's the chemistry between the guys that really sets the screen alight.
It's the back and forth between Tatum and Hill that is the secret weapon, here, and they're firing on all cylinders.
No doubt, he is a great entertainer in his own right. Still, this one is strictly for showbiz buffs and Alice Cooper fans.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: ...a performance beautifully coloured with varying shades of emotion that also makes clever use of [Moore's] porcelain looks to evoke the vulnerability of the eponymous Alice.
In his best performance since The Hurt Locker, Jeremy Renner fires on all cylinders as Webb, a man searching for truth, and perhaps glory.

Araki has a habit of slowly fading from one scene to the next, perhaps in an effort to create a brooding atmosphere, but it's just plain soporific and the occasional bit of dry comedy offers scant relief.
Director Patricia Riggen efficiently touches all the bases without doing what Ron Howard did so well in Apollo 13 - creating an air of uncertainty despite the final outcome being known.

It's a wallop of spectacle and soul-searching that director Alejandro G Irritu serves up in his follow-up to last year's Birdman - a revenge-propelled must-see epic, master-crafted to leave you breathless.
The Boss is a big fat drag of a movie and McCarthy, throwing herself into it with her usual crackling, live-wire energy, can only lift it in places.
It still doesn't make complete sense, but its weirdness remains a virtue.
Is it supposed to be a comedy, or a drama? The tone of the film shifts like the Arabian sands.
A biopic in which the star transcends himself but is badly let down by the storytelling.
Davis bangs on about honesty, but his words and unlikely actions just don't hang together.
An identity crisis is at the heart of this peppy, enjoyably impish thriller that's anchored by Kevin Costner as convicted sociopath Jericho.
It's not quite as elegant as A Beautiful Mind or as charming as Good Will Hunting, but being a true story lends it weight and poignancy.

Any cracks are very efficiently papered over and the result, while not seamless, still has lots to offer, with sterling performances from the female contingent and a couple of other neat twists on the classic fairy tale.
From the perfunctory title to its party-hard finale, My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2 doesn't try too hard, but it still draws you back in with open arms and the same big heart.
There are too few laughs and none of the cool edge you'd expect from the man whose look was "Blue Steel".
Deadpool is certainly rough around the edges, but that's his - and the film's - charm.
In the end The 33 only grabs on a superficial level.
Still waters often run deep, but here, you can't see past the glossy surface.
Director Ron Howard - who is usually a safe pair of hands - steers this ship into choppy waters, apparently unclear on where he wants the story to go.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: In all Daddy's Home is a hollow construction.

There isn't much of a story aside from Poehler's aim to bed the hunk down the road and Fey's attempts to keep a priggish Maya Rudolph from crashing the scene but putting a feminine touch to the standard frat-house formula lends a certain edge.
The Coopers are, quite simply, bad company.
A pacey, involving thriller that hinges on a disciplined turn from Depp.
Cold War paranoia takes you in its icy grip in Bridge of Spies, but you know you're ultimately in safe hands with Steven Spielberg at the helm and Tom Hanks up front.
As a portrait of a tragicomic hero - snigger-inducing yet ultimately heart-warming - it's an irresistible bit of chilled-out entertainment.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There's never a dull moment in War Dogs and just when you think it can't get any crazier, it blows your mind.
Jon Lucas and Scott Moore, who co-direct as well as co-write, struggle to find focus and the result is a film as tired and scattered as its sleep-deprived heroine.
If you like your jokes raw and saucy, Sausage Part hits the spot.
If it doesn't quite smoulder as it should, Claflin's brooding performance, along with the sterling support, at least helps to envelop you in the mystery.
Miller keeps CGI to a minimum in favour of breathtaking choreographed stunts, but he does exploit modern cameras to weave between vehicles as they roar, crunch and groan with thrash-metal musicality.
movie_title: Mad Max: Fury Road: Black & Chrome (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's impossible not to be moved, even with such a polite rendering of events that, in the end, finds hope for the human species.

Its bluntness at times means Ghost in the Shell probably won't go down as a classic, but it does keep the cogs turning and if the ticket sales warrant it, there's ample scope for a sequel to flesh out this fast and furious fembot.

The actors do well to convey enough sweaty desperation while hanging on to their dignity, and they make a workable unit to combat the threat - not just of the alien, but of the occasional dips in the movie's energy.

Gray delivers a very subdued film overall, right down to the washed-out visuals, but the doggedness of Fawcett sparks a sort of morbid fascination with how far he is willing to go to prove his theory.

While the film might have gone further in laying bare the true scale of the political subterfuge and the upheaval it caused, it is refreshingly blunt about a period of history often viewed through a rose-tinted lens.
Even if some details have been massaged to fit the template of a Hollywood crowd-pleaser, the main thrust of the story is true and all the more remarkable for that.
Like Billy, this portrait is flawed yet noble and sensitive.
With a hint of crazy in his eyes and a lot of fire in his (very ample) belly, McConaughey encapsulates everything that a treasure hunter should be.
This is clearly Smith's show. She is funny without tipping into caricature, yet openly vulnerable ...

T2 doesn't quite tap the zeitgeist in the same way as the first film, but what it does do is find the heart in a bunch of characters who were once defined by not caring -- so hopped up on skag they would rip offer their own mams.
It mightn't be exciting enough for some viewers, but Hanks is a big presence and carries this one home with great skill and composure.
The charm of the original was in seeing this misanthrope put under pressure by so much good will, but, like Thornton's ill-fitting beard, the balance has tipped too far the other way.
In the context of 1940s cinema, the occasional overblown moment makes sense as well, and if you don't feel a lump in your throat by the final curtain, you may want to consider a career in espionage.

Ben Affleck will have relished the idea of subverting the image of the mild-mannered pen-pusher, but this drama from Jane Got a Gun director Gavin O'Connor ties him up in knots with twists and turns that all add up to zero.
While the ever-game star jogs around quaint European landmarks with a look of mild consternation, director Ron Howard struggles to inject real urgency into proceedings.

Director Tate Taylor has created a very neat (if rather too tidy) domestic thriller, but he hasn't exploited the medium to bring anything fresh to the story, riding instead on the solid track the book provides.

McConaughey - having risen from the ashes of many a rubbish romantic comedy in the noughties - here again demonstrates the kind of deeply dug intensity that can elevate a merely average film to greater heights.
Burton fans will come away from this feeling utterly spoiled.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While there is nothing particularly awful about this remake of the 1959 ancient-world classic, the brash, breakneck style - obviously geared towards a young, modern audience - renders it less epic.
Even if the machinations of the plot are highly unlikely and predictable, like the best British comedy, there are moments that make you cringe as well as laugh out loud.
There is rarely a dull moment, but if Affleck had thrown more light on the darkest corners of Joe's mind, Live by Night could have been a classic.
Hiddleston is brilliant. He pulls off a delicate balancing act, never tipping too far into sulky self-indulgence and Swinton is a reliable anchor with her no-nonsense approach to immortal life.
There's lots of food porn, but the overall sensation is one of emptiness.
A lean, mean spoof on the music industry for those who believe The X Factor marks the decline of western civilisation.
Substance doesn't quite match up to the high style of this ethereal western, but Michael Fassbender lends weight as the gruff gunslinger who rides along with the kid...

Sherlock fans may also be frustrated by the lack of a traditional, forensic investigation, but as the study of a troubled psyche - with Holmes only knowing for sure that the end is near - it is quietly compelling.
This is McCarthy's show. She carries the film with huge charm, razor-sharp comic instincts and surprising chop-socky skills.
Collins keeps his sense of humour, and Pacino even outshines his razzle-dazzle zoot suits.
Bell is funny to the bone, but she also has that rare combination of intelligence, grit and vulnerability which keeps the film from being overly fluffy.
Al Pacino gets his groove back as ageing rock star Danny Collins in a lively comedy-drama that draws from his own star aura and sends it up, too.
When all is said and done, this movie may not change the world, but it demands courage from those who might have the necessary spark to do so. That, in itself, is a great endeavour.
Rock is quite inventive, jumping back and forth, in and out of conversations, to create a stream of consciousness feel without tying the story in knots.

There are pale shades of '80s yuppie comedies, too, like Something Wild and After Hours, but those films deliver their kicks from seeing stiff collars come completely undone. Throughout, Lilibet is just too decorous.
Just as it was in the first film, the sequel is all about the shamelessly wicked one-note gags, delivered hard and fast between countless kooky renditions of songs you haven't heard for ages.
Shirley MacLaine and Christopher Plummer rise above the patronising cuteness imposed by co-writer/director Michael Radford (Il Postino) in this tale of a late-blossoming love affair.
You cannot fail to be moved by this story of young Sudanese refugees - and not just to tears either.
It's the stuff of Sunday night TV drama, for winding down with tea and cake. Very civilised.
It's an intriguing David vs Goliath battle and Mirren positively glows with indignation.
Hawke gives a complex, sensitive portrayal and if Niccol sometimes flounders in externalising that inner conflict, it doesn't detract from the intensity.
[Crowe] has taken some easy shortcuts, but his future in directing looks bright as the Anatolian sunrise.
Will Ferrell is looking at ten years in the slammer in a comedy that delivers a hard slap in the face to political correctness.
The unusual mix of laughs, lunacy and a touch of melancholy ensures The Voices will stick in your head.
With this effort, Penn is way off the mark.
Reynolds has never been more charming or spine-chilling - often simultaneously - in what is a genuinely multifaceted tragicomic performance.
Bier gives Waldau room to work rather than fall back on the usual tricks of melodrama (a swelling string section and extreme close-ups) and he carries the film scene-by-scene.
Too many voices create a chaos in front as well as behind the camera without the requisite comedic payoff.
Viewers are more likely to find this funny in the sense of strange.
The initial banter between the lads - some of which is actually quite endearing and funny - eventually gives way to cheesy scenes designed to titillate rather than tickle the funny bone.
Not all the gags are inspired and the excessive swearing can feel like a substitute for actual jokes, but even if this isn't solid comedy gold, it's still much funnier than a lot of other fluff.
Winding, tense and unpredictable right up to the last spin of the roulette wheel.
Imagine a parallel universe where Harry Potter got pumped up on steroids and you'll have an idea of what to expect from The Last Witch Hunter.
Frears only circles around the real Lance Armstrong, watching him as he builds his legend and countering that with an enigma.
Armstrong may have been obsessed with crafting his own myth, but Frears only offers us a shadow of the man.
In a sense everything is a little too entertaining to ring true.
While it never quite thrills, you soon settle into the relaxed rapport and easy rhythms of a decent comedy - albeit one that is distinctly beige, and almost instantly forgettable.
Not so much entertaining as it is enraging, 99 Homes gets in your face with the injustices suffered by countless hardworking people in the global financial crisis.
This is a survival story marked by passivity, where those involved must simply bow down to the power of nature and hope for the best.
Based on tragic events from 1996, this story of survival on the world's highest mountain feels surprisingly small.
With so many high-octane thrills, fans will be left breathless ahead of the final leg of the journey, The Death Cure, due out in 2017.
An unusually pitched portrait of a culinary genius from the Gordon Ramsay school of shouty chefs who needs to learn to, like, chill out. But that high energy never fully translates to the screen.
This doesn't feel like the Krays' definitive story, more a seductive tribute to how they cornered their place in London's history.
It's rib-ticklingly funny, full of witty exchanges and neat visual flourishes by director Alfonso Gomez-Rejon.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Mad Max creator George Miller brings the futuristic franchise thundering back to life, a lot less lean but just as mean, more than three decades after Mel Gibson donned the leathers.
Haigh brings unbearable tension to almost every shot, even briefly riffing on haunted house film conventions as a door slowly and symbolically swings shut behind Kate.
Only men of a certain age are likely to get a rise out of this.
... a heartfelt, consistently funny film that deftly sidesteps its potential cliches at every turn.
James Bond may have cornered the market in '60s-inpsired spy flicks, but director Guy Ritchie's The Man from UNCLE offers a fizzy antidote to 007's deep psychological probing of late.
Overworked yet underdeveloped; watching this movie is like watching a dog chasing its tail and just about as funny.
Fuqua tends to amplify the melodrama - with music and lingering close-ups - and especially towards the end, but the film never quite socks you in the gut the way it should.
Even though it isn't as lean and mean as the first film, Ted 2 is still a bagful of naughty fun.
Aside from the lightbulb moments that produced hits like 'God Only Knows' and 'Good Vibrations', the film lacks real dynamism.
Ricki is fun to be around, but like the memory of watching this, she's not the kind that sticks around.
It's a hard premise to buy in to, but there's plenty of rib-tickling banter between Frost and his co-stars ...

The idea that brother and sister experienced the same events through different eyes is a clever one, but Flanagan doesn't get behind it with any conviction and the constant flashbacks only keep flipping the lid off the pressure cooker.
His frame is slight, but Matthew McConaughey remains a hulking presence in this riveting true-life tale.
It's fair to say that Marshall dropped the ball with this one, too.
Delightfully evocative of a bygone era of film-making.
Downtrodden workers seek payback from a dodgy Wall Street trader in this topical yet goofy action comedy.
Strip away the silliness and there might be a real gem here. It's just that Clooney keeps digging in the wrong places to find it.
By and large it's a comedy of errors, but not as Shakespeare intended it.
There's more than enough charm and good humour here to sweep you off your feet.
The body-swap comedy gets a mighty shake-up here, with Ryan Reynolds and Jason Bateman cheerfully breaking all the boundaries of taste.
The air is as eerily thick as it was in Let the Right One In, painted in the same muted colors, drawing attention to blank spaces that seem to close in on the characters.
Hathaway and Sturgess make great company, with plenty of witty banter to counter the brooding.
What keeps you glued is an almost morbid fascination with how many times over the course of twenty years these soul mates can foul things up before they give in to what is obvious.
At least our would-be murderers enjoy an easy rapport, and this may provide some distraction as the pace slackens and plot continues to go nowhere.
Plummer gives a textured portrayal as Hal, but it's the character of Oliver, sensitively played by McGregor, that rings truest, even when he takes advice from a subtitled dog.
It's a shame the story is so flimsy, because the casting is solid.
It may seem a little too quirky at times, but the film does speak eloquently to a very human malaise.
What keeps the film anchored is the growing unease that Firth exudes in quiet, crushing waves. He's always at his best, single-handed.
The dialogue zings with period flourish and point-blank delivery.
The problem is that our soliloquising Cockney comic as the "world's only loveable billionaire" (as the poster has it) seems too much like a child stamping his feet, demanding that love.

It wouldn't be classic del Toro without the razzle-dazzle. The Golden Army provide that as they finally rise up, but even in the culminating moments of battle, it is del Toro's feel for human grace that shines through.
The guys are just as clueless after a wild night on the town, but getting lost amid the goggle-bright lights of Las Vegas seems like a fairground ride compared to Bangkok.
Coen fans will also enjoy their distinct brand of whip-cracking dialogue, which is almost musical in its rhythms.
The adrenalin rush is fun, but neglecting the character dynamics means that, when the lights go up, Hanna will just be a fleeting memory.
Let your eyes be dazzled and your mind be numbed.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, that feel-good factor overrides occasional moments of discomfort.
If only the structure of the story was as robust as Carano, this thriller would have been hard to beat.
Neeson makes a savagely deep impression in [the] role, perhaps because of the baggage he brings from his real life.
Except for a very silly ending, his film goes down as easily as a glass of bubbly.
It's an exciting chase thriller, but it's thin, playing like the first act of three parts and while Cross is physically strong, he may not have the legs for it.
Admittedly, the film is heavy-handed in places, but it still makes you sit up and take notice.
Newcomers may enjoy the novelty, but it's less involving for those who know where it's all headed, making this not so much amazing entertainment, but more of a passing amusement.
This is one of those comedies where, actually, nothing very funny happens.
There's a dreamlike quality to the action, but it's too fragmented, too fragile to sustain any kind of tension.
Every shot is beautifully composed and Sanders is able to create an atmosphere that draws you into a scene. It's just that, once inside, there are no great reveals.
A funny, exciting, spectacular and surprisingly poignant thrill-ride -- definitely worth two of your Earth hours.
Gibson does well to keep up with all the madcap action and he brings a steeliness that echoes his work in Payback and Edge of Darkness.
Depp could play this role in his sleep and in a way, he does. But still, he's the life and soul of the party.
Whedon doesn't patronise viewers. He strikes just the right tone and where there are rough edges, he uses Iron Man's wry humor to smooth them out. The effect is totally disarming.
What a shame that Binoche goes all the way, only for the director to tell half the story.
A sweet, warm and witty romance that satisfyingly washes over you.
The kids' final performance is a high note -- rousing and true; final proof that you don't need tidy resolutions to spin a lasting memory.
Even with a captivating, Oscar-nominated performance by the star, the servant remains inscrutable beneath that starched collar.
At its best, the film is a joust between Hammer and Roberts to see who can get the most laughs.
Plasticine pirates wreak havoc on the high seas in a gloriously silly caper from Aardman's Animations.
[A] cute comedy drama inspired by a true story.
It's all very glossy, yet remains an emotionally arid affair.
Ultimately, there's no danger of being deeply moved by this film - it's just a tantalising glimpse of part of what makes us human.
Fresnadillo fails to build enough suspense.

Bloodless on every level.
Thankfully, there is light at the end of the tunnel. Just don't expect any grand revelations before the curtain falls.
As usual, when the filmmakers get in over their heads it's Depp who must wade in and get them out of trouble.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: While another actor might lose your sympathy, Giamatti effectively portrays the quiet desperation of a decent man on the edge, and it's his soul-searching turn that keeps you pinned to your seat.
Depp retains the ability to rise above the nonsense with his customary sly humour.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: [It's] saved by no-nonsense acting, and Kwanten stands firm as the moral backbone of the story; a young cop transferred from the city to a dustbowl town.
Rather than bang us over the head with that hammer, Hemsworth and Kenneth Branagh take a mischievous, light-hearted approach more in keeping with the Marvel Comic than the ancient mythology.
This funny and warm French ensemble effort plays out like an early Woody Allen comedy, with its bourgeois characters, witty banter and relationship intrigues.
For every rock god who ascends to stardom, there are countless wannabes destined to hit rock bottom.
Potentially funny insights are quickly drowned in a constant stream of bodily fluids, like the sweat of desperation as the Farrellys struggle to recapture their own glory days.
Chalet Girl won't melt your heart, but it at least leaves a warm glow.

Apparently unable to extract humor from the situation they've set up, the Farrellys resort to doing what they feel they do best: staging schoolboy gags involving the untimely emission of various bodily fluids.
A genuine, mutual empathy comes across between the leads that makes it all the more easy to root for them.
Broad comic turns by Nicole Kidman and Nick Swardson only exacerbate the feeling that everyone is just trying too hard for their own good here.
Although Superbad's Greg Mottola doesn't have the firm directorial grip of the pair's usual collaborator, Edgar Wright, for the most part this is a far-out, funny ride.
This isn't one for the ages, but it'll do for a Saturday night.
You may root for Sandler and Aniston to just 'go with it', but only so you can be done with it.
Hudson struggles to strike the balance between comedy and tragedy, and she and Bernal share little chemistry.
The emotional breakthroughs are clearly signposted, as if you can feel the filmmaker's hand while she slowly winds our heartstrings around her little finger.

Giamatti skilfully pitches his performance somewhere between brash and pathetic to gradually endear himself.
Even with veteran director Ron Howard behind the camera, proceedings too often veer off in the wrong direction.
