Weakness is the Lantern's greatest strength. If anything, there should have been more chinks in his CG armour.
Diaz has a girlish charm that means she gets away with a series of cynical pranks, even though she's not quite as big and clever as she thinks she is.
Mel Gibson's off-screen exploits have lumbered him with some heavy baggage, so it's surprising to see him embrace that vulnerability in Jodie Foster's oddball comedy.
Maruge comes across more as a paragon than a person, and, like him, you'll be left wanting to learn more.
Mike Leigh is often dumped in the dour, 'kitchen sink' genre of British filmmaking, but that is to overlook his wily sense of humor.
This is a film worth talking about.
It runs out of steam before the end comes into view.
There are some witty observations, but these, along with the use of natural light, have the effect of bringing a bad situation into starker perspective.
More than a comic-book adventure, this is a sprawling crime epic.
The dialogue is functional at best, Bryan's motives are basic; it's all apt for this bare-knuckle punch of an action movie.
It's all a bit of a slog and, in the end, you don't know much more than you did at the start.
It's not the stunts and derring-do which excite the senses as much as the quiet chemistry between Stewart and Pattinson; that is guaranteed to get your blood up.
Chalet Girl comes as a breath of fresh, Alpine air in that it's a very British, no-nonsense story of a working class girl who falls for her posh employer.
Even for an experienced director like Howard, there are just too many problems to get around.
The end result is a beautiful bore.
What we're left with is a straightforward sob story; a haunting, matter-of-fact depiction of cruel injustice that couldn't fail to touch a nerve in any context.
McKay and co. manage to pull off a strangely heart-warming finale.
This is sweet, but it's pure candyfloss.

It's a familiar chain of events that resolves these issues, but where McCarthy veers from the mainstream is in his focus on the small lightbulb moments over the slow-motion slam-dunks that usually mark the reversal in fortunes.
It is far too long and the romance is half-hearted. Still, you'd have to travel very far to feel so fully immersed in another world.

Compared to the rest of the Bond series, Quantum Of Solace is something of an aberration (especially given the unorthodox ending) so it's just as well that Craig stays on target. He is, without doubt, the best Bond thus far.
Wiig's brand of comedy is loud, proud and just gosh darned funny.

In case you miss the joke, McBride helpfully arcs an eyebrow and cocks his head to signal the punchline. And with all the subtlety of Thor, he hammers most of his crude one-liners in the direction of Portman as the vengeful warrior chick Isabel.
The actors don't flinch from the task and there is hope at the end, though it may feel like small reward after so much digging.
The megawatt pairing of Tom Hanks and Julia Roberts brings precious little sparkle to this romantic comedy.
A romance featuring older characters shaped by bitter experience is rare, making it all the more frustrating that Hanks opts for juvenile gags about boobs and bums, and the occasional pratfall.
For both men though, it's the sincerity lurking just beneath the bravado which sets the film apart from the abrasive comedy it might have been.
Don't look for wry satire - the gags are big and brash - but with the duelling stars on top form, The Campaign scores high in the approval ratings.
The acting is heavyweight, as are the moral questions about the personal cost of serving the greater good that propel the story with an unstoppable force.
As a patchwork of historical fact and anecdotal evidence, it is at least very colourful.
Ultimately, this is a comedy that shows a lot of early promise but fails to deliver.
Wiig is always watchable and her comic timing is impeccable, but her bored expression only serves to amplify the monotony of the plot.
The entire cast is short-changed in a film that prioritises cheap thrills over characters you can invest in, and the problem is compounded by a plot that is designed by the numbers.
It's Naomi Watts who takes the biggest gamble here, by playing "the most famous woman in the world" - and it's a losing bet.
Bell, who showcases a rib-tickling array of silly accents, is someone we should be seeing and hearing from a lot more.
You probably wouldn't hit rewind to see it all played out again, although the film does have its moments.
It's a sunny, funny and genuinely heart-warming watch.
On a superficial level, this is quite an entertaining look at the making of Deep Throat - the first film to take pornography into the mainstream.
This is a film held together by hair wax, leather and bondage straps rather than coherent storytelling.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: We're The Millers aims to shock, but the real kicker is that actually, it's not that bad. In fact, it's quite funny (though you may quietly hate yourself for laughing).
This is a movie with genuine heart.
The plot follows a standard formula, but the simple gender twist and great casting keep things sizzling.
Though it frequently lapses into clich, the real-life roots make it extra spine-tingling.

The story becomes chaotic and disjointed, but that's the point: Frances is tumbling towards her 30s with no sense of direction and this is where Gerwig excels, deftly pulling you along on a bumpy ride.
There are halting verbal exchanges, half-smiles and Pearce gazing wistfully out of windows (mourning his youth), all of which creates a dreamy, seductive atmosphere.
The truly revealing aspect of this story is the picture it paints of Stockholm, made up of many colours and creeds, where everyone is carrying baggage from home.
The chemistry between Pegg and Frost still fizzes, but at the same time, Pegg (who co-wrote the script) has created a character in Gary King who is one-note - always turned up to eleven.
Very clearly, this is a women's film devised by men and, for our leading ladies, that's the trap.
There is no-one quite so smug as a magician enjoying the bafflement of the crowd and this alleged thriller, about a rogue team of illusionists, is full of it.
It's as if Google devised a programme to churn out an average Hollywood comedy and offered it to director Shawn Levy (and Vaughn, as co-writer) with a proviso that they make the company look good.
A couple persistently digging at each other might have been insufferable to watch except that Hawke and Delpy manage to be goofy, funny, witty and charming, even while they're fighting.
While comedy is often the best way to challenge taboos, there needs to be real substance to the characters involved and instead, they come across like types.
There's little sense of urgency because Daisy's mission is tough to invest in.
The action flows thick and fast, but so much of what drives the film happens beneath the surface.
One of Holofcener's strengths is her ability to portray female friendships with all their underlying politics, as well as delivering some great salty banter.

As this so-called invisible woman, Felicity Jones has great presence and yet the passion that would drive Dickens to compromise his moral standing is never fully expressed and the "great man" remains a remote figure.
Whatever the jokes lack in originality, Efron makes up for with nicely timed, deadpan delivery.
Mark Wahlberg stands firm as Luttrell and he also produced this version of events which, ultimately, celebrates the brotherhood of soldiers and hits hard, on a gut level.
The story (unevenly structured) doesn't pick up pace until halfway through giving the actors lots of time to dwell on their daily grind, which is fun for them - not so much for the rest of us.
A bold and tantalising performance by Isaac who defies the actor's instinct to let us inside...
Vaughn delivers an unusually heartfelt performance, verging on self-deprecation (as opposed to the usual smugness) and it gives us hope that he's finally growing up.
The violence is starkly pictured by McQueen, lingering on black skin torn apart to reveal milky white flesh and, of course, red blood.
You may be able to tap out every beat of the story before it's been played, but you'll go along with it because of so much star charisma and a heady party atmosphere.
It may have been better aimed at slightly older children, but your little monsters should get a kick out of it.
It's a rousing adventure, in parts; a film of great moments rather than a great film with a pattern of suspense that trails up and down like a hobbit over a mountain range.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: An excuse to wallow in slushy sentiment and Edwardian glamour - best suited to a rainy day at home in the English summer.
It may just be a fly-by-night fancy, but this quirky noir still packs more heat than your average action thriller.
It's very funny and very fresh - in more ways than one.
The good news is that you can't go too far wrong by copying a proven formula and for a new generation of moviegoers, it will be something different.
You can't help feeling that there's more to this story than ever meets the eye.
Given a little more thought, De Niro could have been sinking his teeth into a juicy Chateaubriand, but instead he's left chewing on flabby, tasteless hamburger.
More than just a love story, this Palme d'Or winning French drama depicts a primal hunger - for love, sex and a sense of belonging.
The film becomes a platform for actors to politely vent on their impotence, and for short-sighted bankrollers to pass the buck to the movie-going public for their lack of cojones.
The sense of fun is infectious and at its core this is a simple tale of friendship that warms your heart, even as it chills the spine.
There are no star names here but there are star turns, most notably from Brie Larson...
The fluidity of the film is what makes it refreshing; capturing the waves and rhythms of emotion through a combination of careful scripting and improvisation.
It's easy to imagine the real Helen Lyndon Goff balking at the sentimental touches, but you know what they say about a spoonful of sugar...
A priceless gem of a comedy drama...

Will Smith is the very embodiment of movie star charisma and Jaden might be a chip off the old block, but here, they're obliged to be po-faced and just plain un-cool. This is Earth, but not as we know it.
You'll laugh and you'll cry, sometimes both at the same time.
Finally, a full-blooded and truly original vampire movie, offering an antidote to the Sweet Valley-style sudsiness of the Twilight franchise.

A low-concept film about time travel mightn't sound like much of a trip, but first-time director Colin Trevorrow offers good-natured fun and real substance in place of shiny surfaces and whizz-bang effects.
Apparently there comes a point in every comic's life when, after living on the edge for so long, they reach for the pipe and slippers and start doing toothless family comedies.

Cruise may not be statuesque, but he could be carved out of stone in this role. Imagine the hubris of a man who doesn't bring a gun to the final shootout, relying instead on his bare hands and a rock. Needless to say, the rock makes a bigger impact.
It is a heart-stopping ride and when the water stills, the adrenalin comes from the uncertainty of their situation.
Tarantino is aiming for the gut, and the sheer audacity just blows you away.
Watching this won't save your soul, but only remind you that life, like a magic trick, is a passing amusement.

Like the traditional femme fatale, Anna leaves you wanting to know more.
If there's a certain thrill in watching bad guys getting their brains sprayed across a wall, it's surpassed by the intrigue of having a filmmaker reveal the inner workings of his own mind.
[A] grim and cheerless adaptation of the Charles Dickens classic.
Perhaps too much snarling for the camera over the years has fixed the expression on Clint Eastwood's face, obliging him to take grumpy old man roles.
Like the old man's sleigh, it's designed to offer an easy, breezy ride with a few new bells and whistles added to old-fashioned elements.

Aspects of the original plot have been tweaked, but where it really matters, the Coens and Hoffman demonstrate a surprising lack of inspiration. It all feels so dated.
A deliriously funny and disarmingly poignant love story that's sure to brighten the outlook of even the hardest cynic.
No gimmicks, quirks or high-concept premise: this is one of those rare, quietly engaging films that is simply about ordinary people trying to relate to each other.
The 1930s original feels more cutting-edge than this re-do.
The changing role of women is also an underlying theme in a many-layered but otherwise simply told story.
Accept the film on its own terms, as a period action thriller, and you'll walk away satisfied - assuming your every last nerve hasn't been jangled to jelly.
In its barest form this is a traditional rites-of-passage yarn, dealing in first love and lost innocence, and even with a candid discussion of sex, it's mostly sweetness and light.
Frankly it all feels a bit obvious, perfunctory and dated.
This is the quietest of [Spielberg's] recent films, with an equally unobtrusive, delicately-crafted, totally absorbing performance from Daniel Day-Lewis.
One can only assume there was a big fat paycheck involved for the likes of Robert De Niro, Susan Sarandon and Diane Keaton to negotiate a script with such lack of ambition, laughs and insight.
Leave it, boys. It's been a blast, but you're over the limit.
So many shiny surfaces, spiralling staircases and fluttering curtains tempt you to reach and touch, but whatever you're trying to grasp remains tantalisingly, just out of reach.
A stirring ode to innocence that evokes classics like The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn and Stand By Me.
One of the great surprises of the movie is Kingsley's turn as the Bin Laden-ish bad guy, hamming it up and giving Stark a reality check on who's to blame for all this.
You may be amused, but the laughter like the man, rings hollow.
Feels more Hollywoodland than 'Promised Land'.
It's Hawkes's portrayal, in all its wit, intelligence and childlike naivety, that really captures the heart.
It's a film dripping with Zilberman's passion for classical music and the way it touches the emotions, and because the actors feel it too, you can forgive any moments of discord.
Hedges usually strikes a better balance of darkness and light, but with this film, reveals feet of clay.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Often it's a thin line between genius and madness, and director Danny Boyle just tips the balance the wrong way with this psychological heist thriller.
A late pitch at pathos isn't quite so convincing, but otherwise this is a fresh, funny and poignant snapshot of ethnic life in London.
An intelligently crafted story, which is briskly paced and highly suspenseful - until a crude and puerile payoff in the third act.
Steve Carell evokes the flamboyant, old-school illusionist David Copperfield in a movie that flits in and out of focus, comedically speaking.

Working from Isaac Marion's novel, writer-director Jonathan Levine bends the rules to make the story work and softens the violence, too, but it's still a witty reinvention of the genre like Shaun of the Dead before it.
Apatow adopts a leisurely pace, but this is a story about middle-age after all and when characters are this much fun, you won't be watching the time go by.
For those who favour a good old-fashioned ghost story, bristling with suspense, this film should be embraced with open arms.
The clash of ideas is fascinating because they boil down to what makes us human: are we driven by hope or fear?
Stamp and Redgrave look suitably comfy together, like an old pair of slippers and it's her adoring gaze that softens Arthur's hard edges.
The initial air of mystery dissipates like a fart in a lift that everyone should be too embarrassed to acknowledge.
Raimi strikes just the right balance of dreamy nostalgia and sharp wit. You simply must go off to see the wizard.
Think of it as a Sunday drive, easy and breezy, with good company to pass the time.
Cloud Atlas is never boring. Tykwer and the Wachowskis make a virtue of everything that is unexplained, creating genuine awe and mystery.
This film is a masterpiece of performance, writing and direction, and I haven't been able to shake it for a week.
Thanks in no small part to the incredible performances from the three title actors, who manage to turn twee into tender, hilarious and relatable -- it kind of works.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While he may not have the answers, an endlessly driven, self-aware and accessible progressive commentator like Brand could be the right person to ask the hardest questions.
Weird.
Strangers [on the earth] promises a connection and theme will be found between various travellers found on the Camino, but it doesn't really deliver.
With a soundtrack of old-school hip-hop like Grandmaster Flash, the film is a fantastic origin story of a culture that still continues to exist to this day.
Backpack Full of Cash holds back no punches.
The film is a perfect representation of what an animated film can do-showing life from a different visual perspective.
[Ross] Lynch's portrayal of Dahmer is unsettling and chillingly detached.
While it does shed light on a very real problem, the only new aspect it offers is a statistic that is never given the time it deserves.

The chemistry between the leading men grows organically and it chronologically makes sense for the viewer. These characters take time to feel comfortable with each other and the film takes its time documenting it.
Anyone remotely fascinated with mountains needs to see this film.
It may be harder nowadays to dazzle audiences with fancy visual effects, but Monsters, Inc. 3D proves that smart, imaginative storytelling still does the trick every time.
The story lacks the specialness of a Pixar movie - it retreads the same eco-battle archetypes as FernGully and Avatar - but it's a perfectly appealing explosion of color for a lazy summer day.
Often, you can point to a middling animated film's visuals as its saving grace. But this colonial world, which should feel like an expansive autumnal panorama, feels oddly inert and two-dimensional.
You don't walk into a movie like A Haunted House 2 expecting anything remotely scary or serious, but you don't expect to walk out feeling a terrible sense of dread, either.
At best, this version succeeds as a Sunday school supplement. But the blandness is enough to make you long for Mel Gibson's The Passion of the Christ.
The generational conflict -- overly ambitious parents and their disaffected millennial children -- plays so on-the-nose it almost seems like satire, but it's really just bad writing.
Rom-com tropes like the ''meet-cute'' are so tired that you can't just spoof them -- you have to spoof the spoofs, which this winking David Wain-Michael Showalter parody mostly succeeds at doing.
Scenes between YSL and rock-steady lover Pierre Berg (Guillaume Gallienne) spark, but the film stays too reverent to truly turn heads.
Canny references to '70s television and some genuinely funny moments will give grown-ups enough fuel to cross the finish line.
Disney brilliantly executed another film in the Star Wars franchise, easing the doubts of fans and furthering our expectations on what we can expect from the films to follow.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Bursting onto the film scene, Peele's directorial debut of Get Out was an unexpected success that will give future films to be released in 2017 a run for their money.
While Fifty Shades Darker may be the year's most terrible film, it was hard to hate it; its over-ridiculousness oddly brought humor and entertainment.
Jam-packed with debatable arguments, themes, and imagery, The Birth Of A Nation is sure to stir up an emotion - but in an overloaded fashion.
With a strong director at the helm, Patriot's Day is a successful representation not only of tragedy but of the love, determination and support that can spur out of the ashes.
While the story and performances were strong, The Light Between Oceans is an eternal example of how an adaptation should have stayed a book.
Mr. Right is a perfectly entertaining, harmless little rom-com film infused with some post-modernist fun that sets it apart from your standard Nicholas Sparks schlock.
Alice Through The Looking Glass is as unnecessary as you expect it to be.
3rd Street Blackout has a genuine and relatable feel to it. If you like a feel-good love story based in the modern age, you'll enjoy this film.
With strong symbolism and character credibility, it is easy to overlook the mishaps and to overall enjoy The Accountant.
Anthropoid forces you, even if only for a brief moment, to remember those who survived, yet lost everything and everyone around them.
Collateral Beauty had the potential to be great, yet even with a stellar cast and a seemingly heartwarming idea, the film failed to deliver what it promised its viewers.
War for the Planet of the Apes is a film fans of the Apes saga, and newfound fans of the prequels, will find as a satisfying addition to the series. Believe the hype.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Beauty & The Beast is a remake that honors the original while becoming relatable to a new generation.
Thelma is captivating, chilling, confusing and brilliant.
The Other Side of Hope is a comically dark look at countries handling and views of Syrian Refugees.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The story of Ismael's Ghosts was bewitching, a puzzle of stories and characters that each unlocked the true reality of Ismael's world and life.
Baker & Bergoch's examination of the low class and welfare lifestyle in Florida is eye opening and at times hard to watch.
While The Rider is a compelling story, the tone of the film across the board tends to remain flat - and at times boring.
Wonderstruck delivers on every element of story, craftsmanship, and talent...weaving an intricate showcase that is sure to satisfy.
If you are looking for classic Saw, unfortunately this film only partially delivers, with the same being said for its attempt at fresh originality.
While a good Star Wars film, this was not the best. With issues across the board (technical, character and plot), The Last Jedi does leave much to be desired.

With a multitude of successful hits across television and film, Netflix misses a beat with their latest film The Open House. With a convoluted story and underutilized characters and elements of storytelling, this film falls flat before it even begins.
While nowhere near the best picture of 2018, Fifty Shades Freed does prove itself to be a tantalizing, sultry, and seductive conclusion to the saga of Anastasia Steele and Christian Grey.

With a stunning craft in recycling an overused story telling formula, strong talent to bring it to life and and one of the more accurate depictions of autism, Please Stand By is likely to win you over as successfully as it did me.
While by no means without its faults, The Midnight Man from director Travis Zariwny is a good time horror film that fans of the genre will love.
There is something about mother! that makes you think, that makes you stop and relive the entire film in your mind.
As a saga, the film waxes and wanes, but Davies' feel for the painterly landscape and the exquisite construction of whatever is within his frame never wavers.
Any moments of honesty are immediately drowned out by a blast of heartfelt tunes that assure you the scene you've been watching was significant.
A few moments harp on the sentimental, but overall, this is a powerful addition to the small collection of films dedicated to spreading awareness of this horrific crime.
Based on Michael Crichton's bestseller, this action film plays more like a comedy filled with TV acting and clich one-liners.
The movie style is as volatile as a rebellious teen -- at times veering over the top. The acting is impressive, though, particularly by Reed, Wood, and Hunter.
A substantive yarn that deals with racism, children not fitting in, and the importance of friendship.
Like its predecessor, there's lively animation that will inspire children to tap their feet to the jungle rhythms and parents to recall their childhoods.
Riddled with clich plot devices and dialogue that's as superficial as the glossy fashion magazine the lead character writes for.
movie_title: How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Though families will enjoy the classic story with a cosmic twist, the most valuable gem is the beautiful mix of hand-drawn and computer animation.
Powerpuff Girls, the movie, could use a little more power and a lot less puff in its storyline.
Midnighters occasionally relies on tropes but it makes for an entertaining watch.
Signature Move is visually stunning and does a great job of capturing Chicago and the diversity folded throughout the city.
If you surrender to the style and premise, it's a rich and immensely rewarding film that begs repeat viewing.
There are a lot of stories here, and, perhaps because none of them could sustain an entire film, they all ended up in this one.
movie_title: How to Go Out on a Date in Queens (2006)
